questions.text: A patient presented with a blood pressure of 220/120 mmHg in an altered sensorium. He also had an episode of vomiting and a history of weakness on the left side of his body. Which of the following is incorrect regarding hypertensive management in this case?

choices.text: In hemorrhagic stroke, reduce the BP to less than 160/100 mmHg with antihypertensives to prevent rebleed
In hemorrhagic stroke, aggressive use of IV antihypertensive if SBP > 220
In the ER, multiple blood pressure readings should be taken before starting antihypertensive therapy
In ischemic stroke, BP should be reduced to <140/90 mmHg immediately

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) In ischemic stroke, BP should be reduced to <140/90 mmHg immediately

 

Explanation:

  • In ischemic stroke, BP should not be reduced to <140/90 mmHg immediately.
  • The correct management includes reducing the BP to <185/110 mmHg before administering thrombolytic therapy.
  • Lowering BP too aggressively could compromise cerebral perfusion, potentially worsening the ischemia and increasing infarct size.

 

Hemorrhagic Stroke:

  • BP should be lowered to <160/100 mmHg with antihypertensives to reduce the risk of rebleeding (Option A).
  • If SBP > 220 mmHg, aggressive use of IV antihypertensives is recommended (Option B).

 

Ischemic Stroke:

  • BP should only be reduced to <185/110 mmHg before thrombolysis.
  • If the BP is above this threshold and thrombolysis is considered, lowering it is necessary, but a reduction to <140/90 mmHg can worsen cerebral perfusion.

 

Emergency Management:

  • In a hypertensive emergency, multiple BP readings should be taken to ensure accurate assessment before starting antihypertensive therapy (Option C).
  • This is important to avoid over- or under-treatment.

questions.text:
LMN (Lower Motor Neuron) lesions are associated with which of the following?


	Decrease in muscle tone
	Spastic paralysis
	Babinski positive
	Fasciculations
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 1, 4

 

Explanation:

Lower Motor Neuron (LMN) lesions result from damage to the motor neurons in the anterior horn of the spinal cord or cranial nerve nuclei, leading to the following hallmark features.

  • Decreased muscle tone (hypotonia)
  • Fasciculations
  • Muscle atrophy
  • Absent Babinski reflex
  • Absent or reduced reflexes (hyporeflexia)
  • Flaccid paralysis

 

UMN vs LMN lesion

Category

Upper Motor Neuron (UMN) Lesion

Lower Motor Neuron (LMN) Lesion

Lesion Location

Motor cortex, connection from motor cortex to facial nucleus in pons

Facial nucleus, anywhere along CN VII

Affected Side

Contralateral

Ipsilateral

Muscles Involved

Lower muscles of facial expression

Upper and lower muscles of facial expression

Forehead Involvement

Spared, due to bilateral UMN innervation

Affected

Other Symptoms

Variable; depends on size of lesion

Incomplete eye closure (dry eyes, corneal ulceration), hyperacusis, loss of taste on anterior tongue

 

Motor Neuron Signs

UMN Lesion

LMN Lesion

Weakness

+

+

-

+

-

+

-

+

Reflexes

↑

↑

↓

questions.text: In children with Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS), all are true except?

choices.text: Areflexia of the affected limb is a mandatory diagnostic criteria
Plasmapheresis is not preferred in refractory cases
Intravenous immunoglobulin is the first line of management
Albuminocytological dissociation in CSF is characteristic

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Plasmapheresis is not preferred in refractory cases

 

Explanation:

  • Plasmapheresis is actually preferred in refractory cases of Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS), especially when the condition does not improve after initial treatment with intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG).
  • The standard treatment for GBS involves the use of either IVIG or plasmapheresis, depending on the patient's condition and response to initial therapy.

 

Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS)

  • Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS) is an acute autoimmune disorder that affects the peripheral nervous system.
  • It often leads to ascending paralysis, starting from the lower limbs and spreading upwards.
  • GBS is considered a neurological emergency due to its potential to cause respiratory failure, autonomic dysfunction, and death without timely treatment.
  • Incidence: GBS occurs in 1–2 cases per 100,000 individuals annually.
  • Preceding Infections: In about two-thirds of AIDP cases, a preceding infection triggers an autoimmune response. Common infections include:
    • Campylobacter jejuni
    • Cytomegalovirus (CMV)
    • Epstein-Barr virus (EBV)
    • Zika virus
    • Influenza
  • These infections lead to molecular mimicry, where the immune system attacks nerve structures, particularly the myelin sheath, causing demyelination.

Variants of Guillain-Barré Syndrome:

Variant

Description

Autoantibodies

Acute Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy (AIDP)

Most common in Europe and North America, marked by segmental demyelination.

IgG Anti-GM1, IgG Anti-GQ1b

Axonal Variants (AMAN/AMSAN)

More prevalent in China and Japan, often linked with Campylobacter jejuni infection.

IgG Anti-GM1

Miller Fisher Syndrome

Characterized by a triad of ophthalmoplegia, ataxia, and areflexia, the best-recognized variant.

Anti-GQ1b

 

Autoantibodies in Guillain-Barré Syndrome:

  • Diversity: GBS patients exhibit a range of autoantibodies targeting nerve cells and structures.
  • Common Antibodies: The most common are anti-ganglioside antibodies, which appear in up to 50% of GBS cases.
  • Prognostic Implications: The presence of anti-GM1 antibodies correlates with poorer clinical outcomes, especially in pure motor variants and Miller Fisher Syndrome.

Clinical Features:

Motor Symptoms
  • Progressive ascending paralysis (distal to proximal)
  • Areflexia
  • Weakness in legs, causing rubbery legs and instability to stand
  • Truncal paralysis, quadriplegia
  • Difficulty handling secretions leading to aspiration pneumonia
  • Diaphragmatic paralysis or bulbar palsy leading to respiratory failure within hours, Ventilatory support required in 30% of cases

Sensory Symptoms
  • Glove-and-stocking distribution paresthesias
  • Loss of proprioception
  • Pain in neck/shoulders similar to over-exercised muscles

Autonomic Symptoms
  • Orthostatic hypotension
  • Wide fluctuations of blood pressure
  • Arrhythmias
  • Neurogenic shock

 

Diagnostic Findings:

Category

Findings

Lumbar Puncture

Elevated CSF protein (100-1000 mg/dL) with normal WBC count (albuminocytologic dissociation)

CSF Timing

Normal findings (<48 hours), protein rise seen by 7 days

Electrodiagnostic Testing

Prolonged F-wave latencies, indicating demyelination (early in AIDP)

 

Brighton Criteria for Diagnosis of GBS:

Mnemonic: FAME

Flaccid Bilateral Weakness

Areflexia (Option A)

CytoAlbuminologic dissociation (Elevated CSF protein, normal WBC) (Option D)

Monophasic Illness (Symptoms develop over 12 hours to 28 days)

Electrodiagnostic findings consistent with demyelination

 

Treatment:

  • IVIG (Intravenous Immunoglobulin) (Option C):
    • First-line treatment.
    • It modulates the immune response and helps reduce inflammation.
  • Plasmapheresis (Plasma Exchange):
    • ​​​​​​​Equally effective as IVIG.
    • It removes harmful antibodies from the blood; preferred in refractory cases.
  • Glucocorticoids:
    • Not useful in GBS treatment, as they do not improve outcomes.

questions.text: The CSF findings in bacterial meningitis would include which of the following?

choices.text: Elevated WBC count with normal glucose

questions.solution:
In bacterial meningitis, there is characteristic elevation of CSF protein due to blood-brain barrier disruption and decreased CSF glucose due to increased glucose utilization by bacteria and white blood cells. The typical CSF glucose level in bacterial meningitis is less than 40% of serum glucose. The protein elevation is typically marked, often greater than 100 mg/dL, reflecting significant inflammation and blood-brain barrier dysfunction.

 

CSF Findings in various types of meningitis:

 

Type

Predominant Cell Type

Protein

Glucose

Gross Appearance

Elevated

Elevated

Decreased

Turbid

Elevated

Lymphocytes

Elevated

Decreased

Straw-colored (TB meningitis)

Viral Meningitis

Normal or Slightly Elevated

Lymphocytes

Normal or Slightly Elevated

Normal

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with fluctuating muscle weakness, especially affecting her speech and swallowing. Repetitive nerve stimulation shows a decremental response. Her blood tests are negative for acetylcholine receptor (AChR) antibodies. Which of the following antibodies is most likely responsible for her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Anti-MuSK antibodies

 

Explanation:

  • MuSK is essential for clustering AChRs at the neuromuscular junction.
  • Anti-MuSK antibodies are found in AChR-negative patients, often presenting with bulbar muscle weakness (affecting speech and swallowing).

Autoantibodies in Myasthenia Gravis

  • Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune disorder characterized by muscle weakness due to disrupted neuromuscular transmission.

Types of Autoantibodies

Autoantibody

Target

Effects

Associated Features

AChR antibodies

Acetylcholine receptors (AChR) on the postsynaptic membrane

Blocks signal transmission, leading to muscle weakness

Most common

MuSK antibodies

Muscle-specific kinase (MuSK)

Impairs AChR clustering and maintenance

Found in AChR-negative patients; associated with bulbar muscle weakness (speech, swallowing, chewing issues)
  • Diagnostic Tests
    • Repetitive Nerve Stimulation: Shows a decremental response (decline in muscle activity with repeated stimulation), indicating faulty neuromuscular transmission.
    • Blood Tests: Detect the presence of AChR and MuSK antibodies.

Anti-dsDNA antibodies (Option A): Seen in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), not associated with neuromuscular transmission issues.

 

Anti-TPO antibodies (Option C): Linked with autoimmune thyroid disorders (e.g., Hashimoto’s thyroiditis).

 

Anti-Ro antibodies (Option D): Found in Sjogren’s syndrome and neonatal lupus, not relevant to myasthenia gravis.

questions.text: A 62-year-old patient presents with left-sided arm and leg weakness, right-sided facial paralysis, and difficulty with horizontal eye movements. Based on the clinical presentation, which of the following syndromes is most consistent with these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Millard-Gubler syndrome:

  • Millard-Gubler syndrome, also known as ventral pontine syndrome, is characterized by a combination of ipsilateral cranial nerve (CN) VI and VII palsy with contralateral hemiplegia. The clinical presentation in this case—left-sided arm and leg weakness (contralateral hemiplegia), right-sided facial paralysis (ipsilateral CN VII palsy), and difficulty with horizontal eye movements (ipsilateral CN VI palsy)—is consistent with Millard-Gubler syndrome.
  • This syndrome occurs due to a lesion in the ventral pons, affecting the corticospinal tract (which causes contralateral hemiplegia) and the fascicles of the abducens (CN VI) and facial (CN VII) nerves, leading to ipsilateral facial paralysis and difficulty in horizontal eye movements.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Foville syndrome: This syndrome also involves a lesion in the pons, but it typically affects the paramedian region, leading to ipsilateral facial paralysis, horizontal gaze palsy, and contralateral hemiplegia. However, Foville syndrome often includes additional symptoms like loss of conjugate gaze due to involvement of the pontine tegmentum.

Option B - Benedict's syndrome: This syndrome is caused by a lesion in the midbrain, involving the red nucleus and the third nerve fascicles. It leads to ipsilateral oculomotor nerve palsy (ptosis, dilated pupil, and loss of most eye movements) and contralateral ataxia and tremor. It does not match the symptomatology of the case described.

Option D - Wallenberg syndrome: Also known as lateral medullary syndrome, this condition is due to a lesion in the lateral part of the medulla oblongata. It results in ipsilateral facial pain and temperature sensation loss, contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation on the body, dysphagia, hoarseness, and vertigo. It does not involve cranial nerves VI and VII or cause contralateral hemiplegia.

questions.text: Patient is having a headache and confusion. A brain tumor diagnosis is made. Family history reveals brain and kidney tumors. Choose the correct option:
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - VHL syndrome:

  • Von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) syndrome is a genetic condition characterized by the development of various tumors, including brain tumors (often hemangioblastomas), kidney tumors (renal cell carcinoma), and other tumors like pheochromocytomas. The family history of both brain and kidney tumors aligns with VHL syndrome. This condition is due to mutations in the VHL gene.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Neurofibromatosis: Neurofibromatosis (NF) has two main types: NF1 and NF2. NF1 is associated with cutaneous neurofibromas, café-au-lait spots, and optic nerve tumors, while NF2 is associated with bilateral vestibular schwannomas (acoustic neuromas) and other central nervous system tumors. Although brain tumors are present, NF does not typically present with kidney tumors.

Option B - Li-Fraumeni syndrome: Li-Fraumeni syndrome is a hereditary condition associated with a higher risk of several cancers, including breast cancer, sarcomas, brain tumors, and adrenal cortex tumors. While it is associated with brain tumors, it is not typically associated with kidney tumors. The syndrome is caused by mutations in the TP53 gene.

Option D - Churg-Strauss syndrome: Churg-Strauss syndrome, now known as eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA), is an autoimmune condition that affects small and medium-sized blood vessels. It primarily involves respiratory symptoms, asthma, and vasculitis, but it is not associated with brain and kidney tumors.

questions.text: What is the confirmatory test for the above condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - NMR Spectroscopy:

  • When differentiating between tuberculoma and neurocysticercosis in cases of ring-enhancing lesions, NMR Spectroscopy (Nuclear Magnetic Resonance Spectroscopy) provides detailed metabolic and chemical information about the brain lesions. This technique can help differentiate between various types of lesions based on their biochemical signatures, making it valuable in distinguishing between tuberculomas (due to Mycobacterium tuberculosis) and neurocysticercosis (due to Taenia solium).
  • NMR Spectroscopy analyzes the metabolic byproducts and chemical composition of the lesions, which can help in differentiating between conditions like tuberculoma and neurocysticercosis. It can provide information about the presence of specific metabolites and biochemical changes associated with each condition.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - CBNAAT of CSF:

  • While CBNAAT is excellent for detecting Mycobacterium tuberculosis DNA and is very useful in diagnosing CNS tuberculosis, it is not typically used to distinguish between tuberculoma and neurocysticercosis directly. It confirms the presence of tuberculosis but does not provide biochemical information about the lesion itself.

Option B - PET Scan:

  • PET scans show metabolic activity in tissues and can be helpful in assessing lesions, but they do not provide detailed biochemical or chemical information specific to tuberculoma vs. neurocysticercosis. They are more used for overall lesion characterization rather than definitive diagnosis.

Option D - MRI aerial scan:

  • This term is not a standard diagnostic modality in clinical practice. MRI is used to visualize lesions and their characteristics but does not provide specific confirmation of tuberculoma or neurocysticercosis. It helps in lesion assessment but is not confirmatory for distinguishing between these two conditions.

questions.text: Seizures are seen in what percentage of RTA patients with brain contusion/loss of consciousness?

choices.text: No relation between trauma and seizures

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Development of seizures in 17%

Explanation:

  • Post-traumatic seizures occur in approximately 17% of patients with brain contusion, subdural hematoma, or prolonged loss of consciousness.
  • Convulsions are uncommon immediately after traumatic brain injury, though brief tonic extensor posturing or clonic movements may occur at impact. Penetrating injuries carry a particularly high risk of subsequent epilepsy development.

45% (Option B), 75% (Option C) & No relation (Option D) are incorrect values for seizures in RTA patients with brain contusion/loss of consciousness.

questions.text: A patient had features of resting tremors, bradykinesia, and postural instability. He became bedridden and died due to respiratory failure. A brain biopsy is likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Lewy bodies

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation of resting tremors, bradykinesia, and postural instability is characteristic of Parkinson's disease.
  • Lewy bodies are the pathological hallmark of this condition, representing eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions containing both neurofilaments and α-synuclein.
  • The disease is characterized by degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta, leading to reduced striatal dopamine. These pathological changes manifest as the classic motor symptoms seen in this patient.

Pathophysiology of Parkinson’s Disease

Initial Damage

Damage to substantia nigra

Consequence

Loss of dopaminergic neurons in substantia nigra (pars compacta)

Effect

Decrease in dopamine production

Autopsy findings

Depigmentation of substantia nigra

Microscopic findings

Inclusion bodies called Lewy bodies

Composition of Lewy Bodies

Composed of α-synuclein (intracellular eosinophilic inclusions)

 

Hirano bodies (Option B): These inclusions are typically observed in ALS and Parkinsonism-dementia complex, not in classic Parkinson's disease.

Guarneri bodies (Option C): These are cytoplasmic inclusions found specifically in cells infected with smallpox or vaccinia virus. They have no association with movement disorders or neurological conditions like Parkinson's disease.

Negri bodies (Option D): These are eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions found in neurons infected with rabies virus, containing viral proteins and RNA. They are diagnostic of rabies infection.

questions.text: The patient is having the following hand movements. In which of the following conditions would this be seen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hypercarbia

Explanation:

  • The typical hand movements shown in the image are known as asterixis or "flapping tremors. These characteristic hand movements are seen in patients of toxic-metabolic encephalopathy, potentially due to hypercarbia.

The 3 causes of toxic-metabolic encephalopathy include:

  • Hepatic encephalopathy (Increased level of ammonia)
  • Uremic encephalopathy (Increased level of urea)
  • Hypercarbia (Increased level of CO2)

This condition occurs frequently in patients with chronic CO2 retention, particularly those receiving oxygen therapy for emphysema or chronic pulmonary disease. The flapping movement is elicited by having patients extend their arms and bend their wrists back.

 

Thyrotoxicosis (Option A) presents with fine tremors. The tremor pattern is distinctly different from the coarse flapping movements seen in asterixis.

Hemiballismus (Option C) manifests with wild, flinging movements at the shoulder joint. These movements are abrupt and unilateral compared to the bilateral wrist movements seen in asterixis.

Hypoxia (Option D) typically causes disorientation and mental status changes with O2 saturation <90%. While it can cause neurological symptoms, it does not specifically produce the characteristic flapping tremor seen in this case.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the outpatient department with complaints of daytime sleepiness and nighttime sleeplessness. His wife reports that he snores at night. Which of the following statements about his condition is incorrect?

choices.text: The tone of the pharyngeal muscles is increased
Low oxygen saturation triggers waking up at night
Episodes of apnea increase stress on the heart

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - The tone of the pharyngeal muscles is increased: 

  • The scenario depicts obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). In individuals with a collapsible airway, reduced muscle tone leads to brief pharyngeal collapse (apneas) or near-collapse (hypopneas). These episodes typically end with ventilatory reflexes prompting arousal, increasing muscle activity, and reopening the airway. Collapse can occur at various sites, including the soft palate (most common), tongue base, lateral pharyngeal walls, and/or epiglottis.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Low oxygen saturation triggers waking up at night: Apneic episodes are related to stress on the heart and waking up at night.

Option C - Episodes of apnea increase stress on the heart: Intensified snoring can lead to apneic episodes, stressing the heart. Rapid fluctuations in heart rate due to hypoxia induce peripheral vasoconstriction.

Option D - Low oxygen stimulates respiratory effort: Hypoxia is the trigger that stimulates respiratory effort in a patient with obstructive sleep apnea.

questions.text: All of the following is a risk factor for secondary headache and need further workup except?

choices.text: 50 years old with first severe headache
Presence of cord-like vessels in the temporal area

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Cocaine abuse: 

  • Cocaine usage is not a factor of concern as cocaine itself contributes to the development of headaches as it causes vasoconstriction and increases blood pressure.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 50 years old with first severe headache: In an elderly new onset headache is a cause of concern and needs further investigation.

Option B - Presence of cord-like vessels in the temporal area: Cord-like vessels are a feature of giant cell arteritis. Hence, the presence of cord-like vessels in the temporal area is a risk factor.

Option D - Subacute worsening of headache symptoms: Subacute worsening of headache symptoms is suggestive of intracranial space-occupying lesions. Therefore, it is a risk factor for secondary headaches.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents with generalized muscle weakness and protrusion of the eyelids (ptosis) that worsens as the day progresses. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Myasthenia Gravis

Explanation:

  • The clinical manifestations indicate Myasthenia Gravis (MG), an autoimmune disorder affecting the neuromuscular junction.

Clinical Features of Myasthenia Gravis:

  • Fatigable muscle weakness: Muscle strength decreases with continued use, especially:
    • Later in the day as day progresses
    • After exercise
  • No sensory or CNS involvement, distinguishing it from other neurological disorders.

Common Initial Symptoms

  • Ptosis (drooping eyelid)
  • Diplopia (double vision)
  • Weakness can spread to:
    • Chewing, swallowing, and speaking muscles
    • Limb muscles

Muscle Weakness Patterns:

Affected Muscles

Key Features

Ocular muscles

Mimics central eye movement disorders.

Cogan's lid twitch sign

Upper eyelid rises briefly after looking down for some time.

Shoulder girdle muscles

Difficulty in overhead activities like combing hair.

Respiratory muscles

Weakness may cause respiratory failure and aspiration risks.

 

Fibromyalgia (Option B): This chronic condition is characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain, fatigue, and tender points rather than true muscle weakness. It does not present with ptosis or demonstrate diurnal variation in symptoms.

Myotonic Dystrophy (Option C): This genetic disorder causes progressive muscle weakness with myotonia (delayed muscle relaxation) and primarily affects distal muscles. The absence of myotonia and presence of generalized muscular weakness points away from this diagnosis.

Guillain-Barré Syndrome (Option D): Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS), the acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy, cardinally presents with acute-onset symmetric flaccid limb weakness. This acute ascending paralysis typically begins in the lower extremities and progresses upward.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with a unilateral throbbing headache that worsens with exposure to bright light. She occasionally skips breakfast. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Migraine

Explanation:

  • The clinical manifestations indicate a migraine headache. According to Diagnostic Criteria for Migraine by International Headache Society, criteria includes features such as unilateral location, throbbing quality, and photophobia (sensitivity to bright light).
  • The condition is characterized by recurrent episodes that can be triggered by various factors, including missed meals, as noted in the patient's history of occasionally skipping breakfast. Migraines typically last between 4-72 hours and may be accompanied by nausea and other sensory sensitivities.

Clinical Features of Migraine

Premonitory (Prodromal) Phase
  • Neck discomfort
  • Cognitive impairment (brain “fog”)
  • Mood changes
  • Fatigue
  • Yawning/sleepiness
  • Increased urination and thirst
  • Food cravings

Aura
  • Neurologic disturbances (e.g., visual disturbances like scintillating scotoma)
  • Due to Cerebral vasoconstriction. Therefore prevention is by Vasodilators.

Headache Phase
  • Pain
  • Nausea/vomiting
  • Sensory sensitivities:
    • Photophobia (sensitivity to light)
    • Phonophobia (sensitivity to sound)
    • Osmophobia (sensitivity to smells)
    • Allodynia (pain from non-painful stimuli)
    • Vertigo
  • Due to cerebral vasodilation. So treatment is Vasoconstrictors

Postdrome
  • Tiredness
  • Weariness
  • Impaired concentration

Simplified Diagnostic Criteria for Migraine by International Headache Society:

Criteria:

Repeated attacks of headache lasting 4–72h in patients with a normal physical examination, no other reasonable cause for the headache, and:

 

At least 2 of the following features:

  • Unilateral pain
  • Throbbing pain
  • Aggravation by movement
  • Moderate or severe intensity

 

Plus at least 1 of the following features:

  • Nausea/vomiting
  • Photophobia and phonophobia

 

Hunger headache (Option A) is typically bilateral rather than unilateral and does not present with photophobia or throbbing pain. These headaches are generally diffuse and associated with hypoglycemia due to missed meals, improving rapidly with food intake.

Tension headache (Option C) presents with bilateral, steady, pressing pain rather than unilateral throbbing pain. These headaches typically feel like a tight band around the head and are not characteristically aggravated by light or accompanied by photophobia.

Cluster headache (Option D) presents with severe, strictly unilateral pain centered around the eye, often accompanied by autonomic symptoms such as lacrimation and nasal congestion. These headaches occur in clusters lasting weeks to months, with multiple short-duration attacks per day, and typically do not have the strong association with photophobia seen in this case.

questions.text: A lumbar puncture was performed on a patient in a sitting position, and the patient is now experiencing a very severe headache. Which of the following is NOT a recommended management strategy for a post-lumbar puncture headache?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Restrict water intake

Explanation:

  • The clinical manifestations indicate a post-lumbar puncture headache (PDPH). Restricting fluid intake is not a standard approach used in the management of PDPH
  • Postdural puncture headache (PDPH) is a potential complication of a lumbar puncture, with symptoms caused by traction on pain-sensitive structures from low cerebrospinal fluid pressure (intracranial hypotension) following a leak of cerebrospinal fluid at the puncture site. Traumatic needles like Quincke, Babcock and also needles with lower gauge can cause PDPH.
  • Definitive treatment with an epidural blood patch is recommended when symptoms persist even after conservative treatment.

 

Management of PDPH:

  • Bed rest for 8-12 hours
  • Analgesics
  • Intravenous caffeine
  • Despite symptomatic treatment, if the headache persists:
    • Low Volume Blood patch: For this procedure, 10 ml to 30 ml of autologous venous blood is injected by an anesthesiologist into the epidural space at the level of the prior procedure. This is thought to create a "patch" over the dural puncture and decrease CSF leak, or simply increase the intracranial pressure.

 

Lie in a supine position (Option A) is a recommended first-line management strategy for post-lumbar puncture headaches. The supine position helps reduce cerebrospinal movement and fluid leakage through gravity and allows the dura to seal.

Administer intravenous caffeine (Option B) is an appropriate intervention for post-lumbar puncture headaches. Caffeine acts as a vasoconstrictor, which can help reduce the headache by decreasing cerebral vessel dilation and improving cerebrospinal fluid production.

Perform a low-volume blood patch (Option D) is a definitive treatment option for persistent post-lumbar puncture headaches that don't respond to conservative measures. This procedure involves injecting autologous blood into the epidural space to seal the CSF leak and provide headache relief.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man experiences initial paralysis in both legs, which then progresses to affect both upper limbs as well. Over time, he shows slight improvement in upper limbs but no improvement in his lower trunk and both legs. Based on this description, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Diplegia

Explanation:

  • The clinical manifestations indicate diplegia, a condition characterized by symmetric paralysis that predominantly affects the lower body while sparing or minimally affecting the upper limbs.
  • The patient's clinical course shows an initial widespread paralysis that improved to primarily affect the lower trunk and legs, and only slight involvement of upper limbs, which is characteristic of diplegia.

 

Quadriplegia (Option B) refers to paralysis of all four limbs and typically includes the torso. While the patient initially experienced widespread involvement, the final clinical picture with predominant lower body involvement does not correlate with quadriplegia.

Paraplegia (Option C) involves complete paralysis of the lower half of the body, including both legs, but does not affect the arms. The patient's history of upper limb involvement and subsequent improvement makes paraplegia an incorrect diagnosis.

Monoplegia (Option D) refers to paralysis affecting only one limb. The patient's presentation with bilateral leg and lower trunk involvement clearly indicates a more extensive pattern of paralysis than monoplegia.

questions.text:
Patient presents with fever, headache, and vomiting that have persisted for the past 2 weeks. On examination, nuchal rigidity is noted. The results of a lumbar puncture (LP) are as follows:


	Opening Pressure: Elevated
	Cells: Predominantly polymorphonuclear leukocytes (PMNs)
	Sugar: 35 mg/dl
	Protein: 200 mg/dl
	Color: Slightly cloudy appearance


Based on these findings, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Bacterial Meningitis

Explanation:

  • The findings indicate bacterial meningitis based on the CSF analysis such as elevated opening pressure, predominant PMNs, low glucose (35 mg/dl), elevated protein (200 mg/dl), and cloudy appearance.

CSF Findings in various types of meningitis:

Type

Opening Pressure

Predominant Cell Type

Protein

Glucose

Gross Appearance

Bacterial Meningitis

Elevated

Polymorphonuclear Neutrophils (PMNs)

Elevated

Decreased

Turbid

Fungal/Tubercular Meningitis

Elevated

Lymphocytes

Elevated

Decreased

Straw-colored (TB meningitis)

Viral Meningitis

Normal or Slightly Elevated

Lymphocytes

Normal or Slightly Elevated

Normal

Normal or

Turbid

 

 

Meningoencephalitis (Option A) involves inflammation of both meninges and brain parenchyma. While symptoms may overlap, the CSF profile with PMN predominance is more characteristic of bacterial meningitis. Meningoencephalitis typically shows mixed cellular response.

Viral Meningitis (Option B) presents with a different CSF profile including lower white cell count (50-500 cells) with lymphocytic predominance rather than PMNs. Glucose levels are usually normal, unlike the low levels seen here. The protein elevation is typically mild.

TB Meningitis (Option C) typically shows lymphocytic predominance, very low glucose levels, and protein levels often exceeding 250 mg/dl. The course is more chronic, and CSF is usually clear or straw-colored. TB meningitis also characteristically shows a cobweb clot formation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with ptosis, diplopia, and generalized muscle weakness that worsens with activity and improves with rest. She has difficulty chewing and swallowing, especially in the evening. A Tensilon test is positive. Which investigation is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) SFEMG

Explanation:

The clinical presentation strongly suggests Myasthenia Gravis (MG) based on the classic triad of symptoms: ptosis, diplopia, and fatigable muscle weakness. The hallmark pattern of weakness that worsens with activity and improves with rest, along with diurnal variation (symptoms worsening in the evening), is pathognomonic for MG. The positive Tensilon test further supports this diagnosis.

In confirming this diagnosis, Single Fiber Electromyography (SFEMG) is the most sensitive test, with a sensitivity of up to 99%. In cases where there is clinical suspicion of MG, as evidenced by fatigable muscle weakness and positive Tensilon test, SFEMG is done as the confirmatory diagnostic tool. Although SFEMG is highly sensitive, the more commonly done confirmatory test is Repetitive Nerve Stimulation (RNS).

Diagnosing Myasthenia Gravis (MG)

Diagnosis involves a comprehensive approach integrating clinical evaluation and specific diagnostic tests.

Clinical Evaluation: Recognizing the Signs

  • History:
    • Focus on the onset, progression, diurnal variation and fluctuating muscle weakness.
  • Physical Examination:
    • Assess muscle strength.
    • Identify characteristic signs:
      • Ptosis
      • Diplopia
      • Cogan's lid twitch sign
    • Rule out other neurological conditions.

Diagnostic Tests: Confirming the Suspicion

Test

Description

Tensilon Test
  • Administers edrophonium bromide intravenously.
  • May show transient muscle function improvement; not highly reliable.

Repetitive Nerve Stimulation (RNS)
  • Specialized nerve conduction study.
  • Reveals a decremental response in muscle strength with repeated stimulation, indicating impaired neuromuscular transmission.

Single Fiber Electromyography (SFEMG)
  • SFEMG techniques allow assessment of two important features of the motor unit: jitter and fiber density (FD).
  • SFEMG is the most sensitive clinical test for neuromuscular junction disease and is often abnormal in clinically unaffected muscles in patients with myasthenia gravis (MG) and Lambert-Eaton myasthenia (LEM).

Antibody Testing
  • Detects auto-antibodies related to MG.
  • Acetylcholine Receptor (AChR) Antibodies: Most common, block AChR function.
  • Muscle-Specific Kinase (MuSK) Antibodies: Disrupt AChR clustering and stabilization.

Thoracic CT Scan

Essential to rule out thymoma, especially in patients with negative AChR antibody tests.

 

CT scan of the chest (Option A) is used for evaluating thymus gland abnormalities such as thymoma, which occurs in approximately 10-15% of MG patients. While important in the overall evaluation, it is not the primary diagnostic test for confirming MG diagnosis.

Anti-acetylcholine receptor antibody test (Option C) is highly specific for MG and is positive in about 85% of generalized MG cases. However, SFEMG is more sensitive, particularly in seronegative cases where antibody tests may be negative despite clinical disease.

MRI of the brain (Option D) may be useful in ruling out other neurological conditions that can present with similar symptoms, such as multiple sclerosis or brainstem lesions. However, it does not provide specific diagnostic information for MG and is primarily used to exclude other conditions.

questions.text: What is observed in the case of an abnormal accumulation of misfolded protein?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Creutzfeldt jakob disease

  • The disease associated with abnormal accumulation of misfolded proteins is Creutzfeldt Jakob disease affecting the brain.
  • Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease (CJD) is a rare, rapidly progressing brain disorder affecting coordination, memory, and mental functions.

Aetiology:

  • CJD is caused by prions, which are abnormally folded proteins that induce other normal prion proteins to adopt the same harmful shape.
  • These abnormal prion proteins accumulate in the brain, leading to nerve cell damage and the characteristic spongiform appearance (brain tissue with holes).
  • The prion proteins disrupt normal brain functions, causing progressive neurological degeneration.

Main symptoms:

  • Severe mental deterioration (dementia)
  • Involuntary muscle jerks (myoclonus)

Early symptoms:

  • Lack of coordination, walking/balance problems
  • Impaired thinking, memory, judgment, mood changes, anxiety
  • Confusion, insomnia, vision changes, unusual sensations

Progression symptoms:

  • Weakness, blindness, loss of movement or speech
  • Pneumonia, infections, coma

CJD types:

  • Sporadic (unknown cause, 85% of cases)
  • Hereditary (gene mutation, 10-15% of cases)
  • Acquired (rare, from medical procedures or contaminated tissue)
  • Variant CJD (linked to "mad cow" disease, affects younger people)

Diagnosis:

  • EEG, cerebrospinal fluid tests (14-3-3 protein), MRI
  • Brain biopsy or autopsy for confirmation

Treatment:

  • No cure
  • Symptom management (pain relief, muscle jerk control, comfort care)

Nephritic syndrome (Option B) is primarily associated with immune-mediated damage and not the accumulation of misfolded proteins.

In sickle cell anaemia (Option C), while there is an abnormality in the structure of haemoglobin, it does not involve the accumulation of misfolded proteins as seen in CJD.

Megaloblastic anaemia (Option D) is a type of anaemia characterized by the presence of large, immature red blood cells (megaloblasts) in the bone marrow. Megaloblastic anaemia does not involve the accumulation of misfolded proteins.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient suffers from schizophrenia. He is currently receiving clozapine treatment. Why does he require frequent blood monitoring?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Agranulocytosis

  • Clozapine is the drug of choice for treatment-resistant schizophrenia. However, a patient on this medication needs monitoring of his blood regularly due to the risk of agranulocytosis, a common side effect of clozapine.

Mechanism of Action:

  • Clozapine primarily works as a dopamine D2 receptor antagonist, but it also has significant effects on serotonin receptors (5-HT2A and 5-HT2C), which helps reduce symptoms in treatment-resistant cases.

Side Effects:

  • Severe risks:
    • Agranulocytosis: Occurs in approximately 0.3% of users, necessitating regular monitoring of white blood cell counts.
    • Seizures (Option D): Affects up to 5% of patients on doses exceeding 600 mg.
  • Common side effects:
    • Hypersalivation
    • Sedation
    • Tachycardia
    • Weight gain
    • Postural hypotension
    • Rare side effects include myocarditis (Option B).

Cerebral bleeding (Option C) is not a commonly reported side effect of clozapine nor does regular blood tests help in assessing the risk or occurrence of one.

questions.text: An elderly patient was brought to the OPD with complaints of tremors, stoop posture and slow movements. His son also gives a history of the patient forgetting day to day activities. What is the possible cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Lewy body:

  • The scenario here points to the diagnosis of Lewy body dementia which is a neurodegenerative disorder characterised by dementia and signs of Parkinson’s disease.
  • Lewy Body Dementia (LBD) includes Parkinson's disease dementia (PDD) and dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB), which are the second most common cause of neurodegenerative dementia after Alzheimer’s disease.

Prevalence:

  • The incidence of DLB is approximately 7 per 100,000 person-years, with both PDD and DLB becoming more common with age and affecting men more often than women.

Cognitive Features:

  • Common in both PDD and DLB: Severe executive, attentional, and visuospatial deficits with preserved episodic memory.
  • Fluctuating cognition, visual hallucinations, and parkinsonism are key features, especially in DLB.
  • Day-to-day variations in cognitive function are often seen, with periods of confusion or lethargy that resolve quickly.

Motor Symptoms:

  • Parkinsonism in DLB often includes postural instability, which can emerge early or later.

Other Symptoms:

  • REM sleep behavior disorder (RBD) is a common and early sign.
  • Symptoms like anosmia, constipation, depression, and anxiety may precede or accompany the cognitive decline.

Diagnostic Features:

  • PDD typically develops after long-standing Parkinson’s disease with cognitive decline, visual hallucinations, and fluctuating attention.
  • DLB involves early dementia and neuropsychiatric symptoms like hallucinations and fluctuating cognition, occurring alongside or before parkinsonism.

Pathology:

  • Lewy bodies and Lewy neurites are present in key brain areas, including the brainstem, substantia nigra, amygdala, and cortex.
  • These inclusions are composed of α-synuclein aggregates, making LBD a synucleinopathy.
  • The progression follows three stages: brainstem predominant, transitional limbic, and diffuse neocortical.

Pathogenesis:

  • Both genetic factors (e.g., α-synuclein duplications, mutations in the glucocerebrosidase gene) and environmental factors, such as toxins, may contribute to LBD development.
  • LBD might spread via a prion-like mechanism, propagating from peripheral areas like the gastrointestinal system or olfactory bulb to the brain.

Cholinergic and Adrenergic Deficits:

  • DLB shows a profound cholinergic deficit, contributing to cognitive fluctuations and hallucinations.
  • Adrenergic deficits, especially from the locus coeruleus, further impair alertness and arousal.

Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus (NPH) (Option A) can cause a triad of symptoms known as Hakim's triad, which includes gait disturbances, urinary incontinence, and cognitive impairment. The triad is not present in the given scenario.

Hypothyroidism (Option B) can lead to various symptoms, including cognitive impairment, depression, and memory problems. But the given scenario does not provide any relation to it.

Vitamin B12 deficiency (Option D) can lead to neurological symptoms, including cognitive impairment and dementia-like symptoms. However, the given scenario is not associated with this.

questions.text: A 60 year old man present with sudden onset of right sided hemiparesis for last 3 hours. BP is 200/100 mmHg. NCCT Head showed brain bleed and right hemiparesis. All of the following are to be done for management, Except?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Thrombolysis:

  • Thrombolysis, also known as clot-busting therapy, involves administering medications to dissolve blood clots. It is typically used in the treatment of ischemic strokes (caused by a blood clot blocking a blood vessel in the brain). However, in this case, the patient's presentation and brain imaging findings suggest a hemorrhagic stroke, which is characterized by bleeding into the brain tissue. Administering thrombolytic therapy in a hemorrhagic stroke could exacerbate the bleeding and worsen the patient's condition, which is why thrombolysis is contraindicated in this scenario.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - BP Control: High blood pressure (hypertension) is a risk factor for both ischemic and hemorrhagic strokes. In the context of a hemorrhagic stroke, controlling blood pressure is crucial to prevent further bleeding and manage the patient's overall condition. So, BP control is an essential part of the management.

Option C - Edema Management: Brain edema (swelling) can occur following a stroke, and it can lead to increased intracranial pressure, potentially causing further damage. Edema management might involve measures such as elevating the head of the bed, using osmotic agents, and closely monitoring the patient's neurological status. This is an important aspect of stroke management.

Option D - Elective Hyperventilation: Elective hyperventilation, which involves intentionally increasing breathing rate, can lead to a decrease in carbon dioxide levels in the blood. This can lead to constriction of blood vessels in the brain (vasoconstriction) and reduction of cerebral blood flow. While it was previously used in the management of elevated intracranial pressure, it is generally not recommended due to the risk of worsening cerebral ischemia. Instead, other methods for intracranial pressure control are preferred.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient weighing 80 kilograms has been diagnosed with an acute ischemic stroke and is recommended for thrombolysis with alteplase. What should the initial stat dose in milligrams be?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 8

  • Streptokinase is always given in the form of an infusion over 1 hour but alteplase, some part of it can be given as a bolus shot and the remaining can be given as infusion. 10% of the total dose need to be given in the form of a bolus.

Calculation of the Total Dose:

  • The standard dose of alteplase for acute ischemic stroke is 0.9 mg per kilogram of body weight, with a maximum total dose of 90 mg.
  • For an 80 kg patient: Total dose=80 kg×0.9 mg/kg=72 mg

Administration of the Dose:

  • Bolus Dose: 10% of the total dose is administered as an initial bolus over 1 minute.
    • Bolus dose=10%×72 mg=7.2 mg
  • Infusion Dose: The remaining 90% of the total dose is administered as an intravenous infusion over 60 minutes.
    • Infusion dose=90%×72 mg=64.8 mg

Since the maximum dose of alteplase is 90 mg, and the calculated dose is 72 mg, the patient will receive the calculated dose of 72 mg. The 10 % of this will be 7.2 and the closest option is 8 so the answer is Option A

Incorrect Options:

Option B - 10

Option C - 12

Option D - 15

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with movement disorder and tremors in hand, along with the development of cognitive and emotional problems. Which of the following medical disorders is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Huntington's disease:

  • Huntington's disease is a genetic disorder caused by a mutation in the HTT gene, leading to the accumulation of abnormal protein in the brain. It presents with movement problems (chorea, which are involuntary, random, and brief movements), cognitive decline, and emotional disturbances such as depression and anxiety. The onset usually occurs in adulthood, typically between the ages of 30 and 50. The mutation involves a trinucleotide repeat expansion (CAG repeats) on the HTT gene.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Parkinson's disease: While Parkinson's disease can present with movement disorders and tremors, it typically develops in older individuals (usually after the age of 60). Additionally, cognitive and emotional problems are more characteristic of other conditions like Lewy body dementia, which can be associated with parkinsonism.

Option B - Friedreich's ataxia: Friedreich's ataxia is a genetic disorder that primarily affects the nervous system, causing progressive damage to the spinal cord and peripheral nerves. It is characterized by problems with coordination, balance, and muscle control. While it can lead to movement problems, cognitive and emotional issues are not prominent features of this disorder.

Option C - Alzheimer's disease: Alzheimer's disease primarily affects memory, thinking, and behavior. It does not typically present with movement disorders and tremors. Cognitive and emotional problems are central to Alzheimer's, but the movement disorder symptoms described (tremors, chorea) are not characteristic of this disorder.

questions.text: 65-year-old man is brought to the hospital with complaints of suddenly not making any sense while speaking using non-sensical grammar though he can speak quickly. He could communicate effectively prior to this. Which of the following defect is present in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Fluent aphasia:

  • Fluent aphasia, also known as Wernicke's aphasia, is characterized by fluent and rapid speech, but the speech often lacks meaningful content. People with fluent aphasia produce long and grammatically complex sentences that might be devoid of actual meaning or might include neologisms (made-up words). They typically have difficulty understanding language and may not realize that their speech is nonsensical.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Motor aphasia: Motor aphasia, also known as Broca's aphasia, is characterized by difficulty in producing speech, with limited vocabulary, slow speech, and impaired grammar. People with motor aphasia struggle to form coherent sentences and might experience frustration due to their communication difficulties.

Option B - Anomic aphasia: Anomic aphasia is characterized by word-finding difficulties. People with this type of aphasia have trouble recalling specific words, which leads to pauses and substitutions in their speech. However, their grammar and fluency are relatively intact.

Option D - Conduction aphasia: Conduction aphasia is characterized by difficulty in repeating words and phrases, even though comprehension and spontaneous speech might be relatively intact. People with conduction aphasia have trouble bridging the gap between understanding and speaking, leading to errors in repeating what they have just heard.

questions.text: Scissoring gait will occur due to increases firing of Which of the following nerve?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Obturator Nerve:

  • The obturator nerve innervates the muscles of the medial thigh, including the adductors (adductor magnus, adductor longus, adductor brevis, gracilis, and obturator externus). Increased firing or overactivity of the adductor muscles innervated by the obturator nerve can result in a scissoring gait. A scissoring gait is characterized by the legs crossing over each other during walking due to excessive adduction of the hip and thigh muscles.

Incorrect Options:

Correct A - Superior Gluteal Nerve: The superior gluteal nerve primarily innervates the gluteus medius and gluteus minimus muscles. Increased firing of this nerve would lead to weakness or overactivity of these muscles, resulting in a Trendelenburg gait (characterized by excessive lateral pelvic tilt and hip drop on the unsupported side during the stance phase of gait), not a scissoring gait.

Option B - Inferior Gluteal Nerve: The inferior gluteal nerve innervates the gluteus maximus muscle. An increase in firing of this nerve would affect the function of the gluteus maximus, potentially leading to altered hip extension, but it wouldn't directly cause a scissoring gait.

Option D - Femoral Nerve: The femoral nerve innervates the muscles of the anterior thigh, including the quadriceps femoris muscle group. Increased firing of the femoral nerve and subsequent overactivity of the quadriceps muscles might affect knee extension, but it wouldn't directly lead to a scissoring gait.

questions.text: In a patient diagnosed with Dialysis Dementia, what deposition is seen in the cerebral cortex?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Amyloid beta-2:

  • This is the correct answer. Dialysis dementia, also known as dialysis-related amyloidosis, is a condition that can affect individuals undergoing long-term dialysis due to end-stage renal disease. In this condition, beta-2 microglobulin, a protein that normally gets filtered out by healthy kidneys, accumulates in the blood due to reduced renal function. Over time, these elevated levels of beta-2 microglobulin can lead to its deposition in various tissues, including the cerebral cortex of the brain. This deposition can contribute to cognitive dysfunction and neurologic symptoms in patients with dialysis dementia.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Amyloid beta microglobulin: This is not the correct answer. The term "amyloid beta microglobulin" is not a recognized term in the context of dialysis dementia or amyloid deposition. The accurate term is "beta-2 microglobulin," as explained in option A.

Option C - Amyloid transthyretin: This is not the correct answer. Transthyretin amyloidosis is a separate condition where transthyretin protein deposits as amyloid in various organs, causing systemic organ dysfunction. It is not specifically associated with dialysis dementia.

Option D - Amyloid Beta: This is not the correct answer. Amyloid beta is a protein that is well-known for its involvement in Alzheimer's disease, where it forms plaques in the brain. However, in the context of dialysis dementia, the protein of concern is beta-2 microglobulin, as explained in option A.

questions.text: Antibody seen in Acute Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy will belong to which class?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - (IgG):

  • Acute Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy (AIDP) is commonly known as Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS). GBS is an autoimmune disorder where the immune system mistakenly attacks the peripheral nervous system, leading to inflammation and demyelination of nerves. In the context of GBS, the antibodies produced against components of peripheral nerves belong primarily to the IgG class.
  • IgG is the correct answer because IgG antibodies are the most involved immunoglobulins in GBS. These antibodies target myelin, which is the protective covering of nerve fibers, leading to impaired nerve conduction and the characteristic symptoms of muscle weakness, tingling, and paralysis seen in GBS patients.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - IgM: While IgM antibodies can be involved in certain autoimmune diseases, they are not typically associated with GBS. IgM antibodies are usually associated with early immune responses and are not as commonly found in autoimmune disorders affecting the nervous system.

Option C - IgE: IgE antibodies are primarily associated with allergic reactions and parasitic infections. They are not a characteristic component of the immune response seen in GBS.

Option D - IgA: IgA antibodies are mainly found in mucosal secretions and play a role in defending mucous membranes. They are not typically associated with the immune response involved in GBS.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents with high-grade fever for the past week. On examination neck stiffness and Kernig's sign were positive. CSF analysis showed lymphocytosis protein - 8 g/L, glucose - 20 mg/dl while RBS = 140 mg/dl. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Tubercular meningitis

Explanation:

  • The low glucose, high protein, and lymphocytosis in the cerebrospinal fluid all point to the diagnosis of tubercular meningitis.


Tuberculous Meningitis

Symptoms and Clinical Features:
  • Headache, slight mental changes, and low-grade fever can develop over weeks, often accompanied by malaise, anorexia, and irritability.
  • More severe cases present with confusion, lethargy, neck rigidity, and altered sensorium.
  • Disease progression: evolves over 1–2 weeks, longer than bacterial meningitis.
  • Cranial nerve palsies, especially ocular nerves, are common due to inflammation at the base of the brain.
  • May result in coma, hydrocephalus, and intracranial hypertension if untreated.
  • Cerebral ischemia can result from the involvement of cerebral arteries.
  • Tuberculoma (space-occupying lesion) may cause seizures and focal neurological signs.

CSF Findings:
  • Elevated leukocyte count (up to 1000/μL, predominantly lymphocytes).
  • High protein content (1-8 g/L).
  • Low glucose concentration.

Investigation of Choice:
  • Culture of CSF (gold standard, takes 4-8 weeks, positive in ~50%).
  • Smear for acid-fast bacilli (AFB) (low sensitivity, positive in 10-40%).
  • PCR for Mycobacterium tuberculosis DNA (variable sensitivity).

Imaging:
  • CT/MRI may show hydrocephalus and abnormal enhancement of basal cisterns or ependyma.
  • Tuberculomas appear as contrast-enhanced ring lesions on imaging.

MRI showing ring-enhanced lesions- tuberculoma

Treatment:
  • Empirical therapy is often initiated based on suspicion.
  • Initial drug regimen: Isoniazid, Rifampin, Pyrazinamide, Ethambutol, and Pyridoxine.
  • Duration: 6–12 months depending on response.
  • Dexamethasone (12–16 mg/day) for 3 weeks, tapered for 3 more weeks (recommended for HIV-negative patients).
  • Tuberculoma may require a biopsy for diagnosis.

questions.text: A stroke patient presents with an inability to identify objects but can determine the colour, texture, and shape of objects. Which of the following lobes is involved?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Temporal lobe

Explanation:

  • The inability to identify objects and the ability to determine the colour, texture, and shape of objects refer to visual agnosia, which is caused by lesions involving the temporal lobe.

Features of Left Temporal Lobe Stroke

Features of Right Temporal Lobe Stroke
  • Impaired language and memory: Difficulty with spoken language and remembering verbal information.
  • Fluent (Wernicke’s) aphasia: Fluent speech with incorrect words, affecting language comprehension.
  • Poor visual memory and spatial awareness: Difficulty recognizing visual patterns and spatial information.
  • Prosopagnosia: Inability to recognize faces, including familiar ones.

General Features of Temporal Lobe Stroke
  • Poor memory: Difficulty recalling memories and learning new information.
  • Prosopagnosia: Trouble recognizing faces and objects.
  • Fluent aphasia: Specifically in left-sided strokes, affecting speech fluency but with incorrect word use.
  • Visual perception difficulties: Challenges with interpreting the visual field and surroundings.
  • Trouble processing sound: Inability to differentiate or process sounds correctly.
  • Visual agnosia: Inability to recognize visually presented objects despite otherwise normal visual field, acuity, colour vision, brightness, discrimination, language, and memory.
  • Emotional and behavioural changes: Varying behaviours due to damage to the amygdala, such as aggression, passiveness, or difficulty interpreting facial cues.

Incorrect Options:

Lesions in a patient's Frontal lobe (Option A) can lead to certain symptoms such as trouble with learning, deficits in visual-motor function, executive dysfunction and problems with attention (planning, focusing, and inhibition).

Parietal lobe (Option B): Right - Damage to this area can cause visuospatial deficits (e.g., the patient may have difficulty finding their way around new, or even familiar, places).

Parietal Lobe, Left: Damage to this area may disrupt a person's ability to understand spoken and/or written language.

Unilateral Occipital lobe (Option D) lesion causes contralateral homonymous hemianopia. It is a visual field defect on the same side of both eyes contralateral to the site of the lesion - lesions of the occipital lobe due to the posterior cerebral artery infarct cause homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing.

questions.text: A patient is brought to the OPD by his wife complaining about difficulty in expressing emotions and not taking part in daily activities. On examination, resting tremors and rigidity are noted. Given the possible diagnosis, which part of the brain is affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Basal ganglia

  • The patient's presentation of difficulty expressing emotions, lack of participation in daily activities, resting tremors, and rigidity is highly suggestive of Parkinson's disease.
  • Parkinson's disease is primarily caused by degeneration of the substantia nigra, a structure located in the basal ganglia. This degeneration results in reduced dopamine production, which affects the motor control pathways, leading to the hallmark symptoms of rigidity, tremors, and bradykinesia.
  • The basal ganglia is a group of nuclei in the brain involved in motor control, as well as cognitive and emotional functions. The degeneration of dopamine-producing neurons in the substantia nigra disrupts the communication between the basal ganglia and other parts of the brain, resulting in the characteristic motor and non-motor symptoms seen in Parkinson's disease.

Other Features of Parkinson's Disease:

  • Rigidity: Increased muscle tone causing resistance to passive movement.
  • Resting tremors: Involuntary, rhythmic shaking that occurs when the muscles are relaxed.
  • Bradykinesia: Slowness of movement, making daily tasks more difficult.
  • Postural instability: Difficulty maintaining balance, leading to falls.

Hippocampus (Option B): The hippocampus is primarily involved in memory formation, learning, and spatial navigation, and lesions here can lead to issues with memory and emotional behavior. However, it is not primarily associated with the motor symptoms seen in Parkinson's disease.

Cerebellum (Option C): The cerebellum is responsible for coordinating voluntary movement and balance. Lesions in the cerebellum typically cause ataxia, intention tremors, and gait disturbances, but not the resting tremors or rigidity characteristic of Parkinson's disease.

Premotor cortex (Option D): The premotor cortex is involved in the planning and preparation of movements, particularly in coordinating postural adjustments for voluntary movements. While damage here can affect motor planning, it is not typically associated with the specific motor symptoms seen in Parkinson's disease.

questions.text: A male patient presented to the emergency room with seizures. He has a history of fever, headache, and confusion. An MRI brain was done, and it showed inflammation involving the bitemporal lobe. What is the most likely etiology for this presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Herpes simplex virus

The patient presents with fever, headache, confusion, and seizures, symptoms highly suggestive of encephalitis. Neurological examination reveals personality changes and altered consciousness, raising suspicion for focal neurological involvement.

  • MRI: Shows bitemporal lobe hyperintensities, a hallmark feature of HSV encephalitis.
  • Focal Neurological Signs: Symptoms linked to temporal lobe pathology, such as behavioral changes and impaired mental status.

HSV Encephalitis

HSV encephalitis is a rapidly progressive, life-threatening condition, often presenting with:

  • Seizures: Focal or generalized.
  • Neurological symptoms: Aphasia, ataxia, cranial nerve deficits.
  • Behavioral and cognitive changes: Altered sensorium, memory impairment, personality changes (sometimes misdiagnosed as personality disorders).

Additional Features:

  • Urinary/fecal incontinence.
  • Aseptic meningitis.
  • Dermatomal rashes.
  • Rarely, Guillain-Barré syndrome.

Diagnosis

CSF Analysis:

  • Lymphocytic pleocytosis, normal glucose, mild protein elevation.
  • CSF PCR for HSV: Gold standard with 96% sensitivity, 99% specificity.

Neuroimaging (MRI): T2-weighted/DWI: Hyperintensities in temporal and orbitofrontal lobes.

EEG: Periodic slow-wave activity in the temporal lobes, highly suggestive of HSV encephalitis.

Management

Antiviral Therapy: Early initiation of IV acyclovir to prevent permanent neurological damage.

CSF findings in meningitis
