questions.text: A 32-year-old woman who visits the clinic with complaints of frequent falls and walking difficulties. She also has a history of smoking and type-1 diabetes but no history of hypertension or coronary artery disease. During examination, the patient exhibits weakness in both lower limbs, absent DTR, as well as an unsteady gait. But, there is a decrease in proprioception and vibration sense in both lower limbs. Which of the following statements is correct about the above condition?

choices.text: Only the dorsal column is involved
All these patients with a neurological impairment will show macrocytosis
Vitamin B12 supplements do not improve this condition
Copper deficiency may produce similar symptoms

questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Copper deficiency may produce similar symptoms

Explanation:

  • The patient's clinical presentation is consistent with subacute combined degeneration (SCD) of the spinal cord, which is commonly caused by vitamin B12 deficiency. SCD primarily affects the posterior (dorsal) and lateral columns (Option A) of the spinal cord. Vitamin B12 supplements (Option C) are the mainstay of treatment for vitamin B12 deficiency, and they can improve the patient's condition. And Copper deficiency may also produce similar symptoms. SACD however, occurs secondary to Vitamin B12 deficiency, can present without macrocytosis (Option B).

Subacute combined degeneration

Description
  • Reversible myelopathy mainly involving Dorsal column and Pyramidal column tracts

Etiology
  • Vitamin B12 deficiency: Nutritional (vegetarians) Pernicious anemia, post-gastrectomy, Diphyllobothrium infection

Clinical features
  • Weakness: Corticospinal tract (CST)/Pyramidal tract involvement
  • Loss of vibration and proprioception: Dorsal column tract involvement
  • Ataxia: Romberg sign positive
  • DTR: Absent (Peripheral neuropathy), Babinski sign: Positive (CST involvement)
  • Dementia: reversible with therapy
  • Hyperpigmentation of interphalangeal joints

Investigations
  • Vitamin B12 assay: Methyl malonate/Homocysteine levels estimation
  • Peripheral blood smear: may reveal macrocytosis with hypersegmented neutrophils

 

  • NOTE: SACD can occur without macrocytosis as well

Management
  • Vitamin B12 supplements

Differential diagnosis
  • Hypocupric myelopathy: Serum Cu2+ levels should be checked

questions.text: In hemiplegia caused by an ischemic stroke, which region of the internal capsule is impacted?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Posterior limb

Explanation:

  • When an ischemic stroke occurs in the area supplied by the blood vessels surrounding the posterior limb of the internal capsule, the motor fibers within this region can be damaged. This results in hemiplegia on the opposite side of the body from the affected internal capsule.

Small vessel stroke:

Cause
  • Lacunar infarct (affecting penetrating branches) secondary to atherosclerotic occlusion/lipohyalinosis

Risk factors
  • Hypertension: Most common
  • Diabetes
  • Atrial fibrillation
  • Smoking
  • Hyperlipidemia

Sites & manifestations

Posterior limb of internal capsule

Pure motor hemiparesis

Genu of internal capsule

Clumsy hand dysarthria lacunar syndrome (facial weakness)

Cortical pontocerebellar tract

I/L ataxia + C/L hemiparesis

Ventroposterolateral thalamus

Dejerine-Roussy syndrome

 

Tracts Passing Through Internal Capsule:

  • Genu:
    • Corticonuclear tract (motor fibres to cranial nerve motor nuclei)
  • Posterior Limb:
    • Corticospinal tract (motor fibres to the contralateral spinal cord)
    • Corticopontine fibres from the parietal, temporal, and occipital lobes
    • Fibres for the upper limb (anteriorly) and trunk/lower limbs (posteriorly)
    • Superior Thalamic Peduncle (through anterior and posterior limbs): From ventral posterior and lateral posterior thalamic nuclei to parietal cortex (sensory areas).

Other Tracts Passing Through the Internal Capsule:

Anterior limb

Retrolentiform part

Sublentiform part
  • Frontopontine fibres (Arnold's bundle)
  • Corticorubral fibres
  • Parietopontine,occipitopontine, and occipitotectal fibres
  • Optic radiation
  • Temporopontine fibres
  • Auditory radiation (fibres from the medial geniculate body to the auditory cortex)
  • Thalamic fibres to the temporal cortex and amygdala.

questions.text: Which of the following causes the slowing of conduction in multiple sclerosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Loss of myelin sheath

Explanation: The slowing of conduction in multiple sclerosis is due to the loss of myelin sheath.

Multiple sclerosis

  • Multiple sclerosis (MS) is an autoimmune disease of the central nervous system characterized by chronic inflammation, demyelination, gliosis (plaques or scarring), and neuronal loss.
  • The course can be relapsing or progressive.
  • Pathophysiology:
    • Immune hypothesis: Increased T lymphocytes in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) and higher immunoglobulin synthesis in the CNS
    • Blood-brain barrier (BBB) injury: Activated T lymphocytes cross the blood-brain barrier, recognize myelin antigens on nervous system antigen-presenting cells (microglia) and proliferate
    • Demyelination:
      • Inflammatory cascade releases cytokines, leading to oligodendrocyte- myelin destruction by macrophages
      • Lesions: disintegration of myelin, lymphocyte/macrophage infiltration, and perivascular inflammation
      • Ectopic lymphoid follicles are linked to demyelination and neuronal loss in the cerebral cortex
      • Diffusible factors from these lymphoid cells may cause demyelination and neurodegeneration
    • Axonal damage:
      • Demyelination reduces trophic support for axons, redistributes ion channels, and destabilizes action potential membrane potentials
      • Neuronal and axonal death may result from glutamate excitotoxicity, oxidative injury, iron accumulation, and mitochondrial failure
      • Inflammatory mediators like nitric oxide initiate and worsen axonal damage
      • Axons can adapt initially to these injuries, but over time, distal and retrograde degeneration (“dying-back” axonopathy) occurs
      • Axonal loss accumulates over time due to repeated attacks and lack of neurotrophic factors from oligodendrocytes
    • Plaque formation:
      • After acute attacks, gliosis occurs by astrocyte cells, forming scars.
      • Surviving oligodendrocytes partially remyelinate axons causing shadow plaques.
    • Oligodendrocyte precursor cells often fail to differentiate into myelin-producing cells.
    • Long-term myelin loss leads to reduced impulse propagation and conduction block, impairing CNS functions.

 

 

Gliosis (Option A): This refers to the proliferation of glial cells (especially astrocytes) in response to central nervous system injury. While gliosis occurs in MS as part of the tissue response to demyelination and inflammation, it is not the primary cause of slowed conduction. Instead, it is a secondary effect resulting from the damage.

Defect at the Node of Ranvier (Option C): Nodes of Ranvier are small gaps in the myelin sheath where voltage-gated sodium channels are concentrated, allowing for the rapid "jumping" of action potentials (saltatory conduction). Although defects at these nodes can disrupt impulse propagation, in multiple sclerosis the main problem is the loss of myelin rather than a defect in the nodes themselves.

Leaky Na⁺ Channels (Option D): In demyelinated axons, the redistribution or abnormal functioning of sodium channels can occur, which may contribute to conduction issues. However, this change is a consequence of myelin loss rather than a primary cause of conduction slowing. The loss of the insulating myelin sheath is the key factor impairing the proper function of these channels.

questions.text: A lesion at which level produces incongruous homonymous hemianopia with Wernicke's pupil?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Optic tract

  • Wernicke's pupil occurs due to a lesion at the optic tract, leading to incongruous homonymous hemianopia.

Wernicke’s Hemianopic Pupil:

  • Indicates a lesion in the optic tract.
  • Light Reflex: Ipsilateral direct and contralateral consensual light reflexes are both absent in the affected areas.
    • Absent when light is shone on the temporal half of the retina of the affected side and the nasal half of the opposite side.
    • Present when light is shone on the nasal half of the affected side and the temporal half of the opposite side.

Visual cortex (Option B): Lesions in the visual cortex, located in the occipital lobe, cause congruous homonymous hemianopia (same field defect in both eyes) and do not produce Wernicke's pupil, which is specific to lesions in the optic tract.

Optic radiations (Option C): Lesions in the optic radiations also result in congruous homonymous hemianopia but do not lead to Wernicke's pupil.

Optic nerve (Option D): Lesions in the optic nerve cause monocular vision loss (loss of vision in one eye), not homonymous hemianopia, and therefore do not result in Wernicke's pupil.

questions.text: An elderly woman is brought to the OPD with complaints of behavioural change, a history of multiple falls, urinary incontinence, and dementia. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Normal pressure hydrocephalus

Explanation: The patient's symptoms of behavioral changes, falls, urinary incontinence, and dementia are indicative of Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus (NPH), which is commonly associated with the classic triad of gait disturbance, urinary incontinence, and cognitive decline.

 

Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus (NPH)

NPH is often idiopathic but can result from prior injuries affecting cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) dynamics, such as subarachnoid hemorrhage.

Clinical Triad
  • Gait disturbance: Progressive difficulties in walking
  • Urinary issues: Urgency or incontinence
  • Cognitive impairment: Decline in cognitive functions

Imaging Characteristics
  • Ventriculomegaly is typically seen
  • Evans ratio: the ratio of the maximum width of frontal horns to inner table width of more than 0.31 is often used for evaluation but has low diagnostic accuracy.
  • An acute callosal angle (less than 90°) on coronal MR images is another measurement used, also with limited accuracy.
  • A disproportionately enlarged subarachnoid space hydrocephalus is seen having ventriculomegaly combined with sulcal effacement at the vertex and scattered enlarged sulci.
  • CSF flow study shows hyper-dynamism with a streak of flow void through cerebral aqueduct.

 

 

Frontotemporal dementia (Option B) (FTD) primarily affects personality, behavior, and language, often presenting with early changes such as disinhibition, apathy, and loss of empathy. Urinary incontinence is not a typical early feature of FTD, and gait disturbances or falls are also not commonly seen at the onset, making it less likely in this case.

Parkinson's disease (Option C) primarily presents with motor symptoms such as bradykinesia, resting tremor, rigidity, and postural instability. While dementia and falls can occur in the later stages, urinary incontinence is not a typical early feature, and the behavioral changes in Parkinson's disease are usually associated with the later stages or due to medication effects, which makes it less consistent with the initial presentation.

Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (Option D) (CJD) is a rapidly progressive neurodegenerative disorder caused by prions, characterized by rapidly progressing dementia, myoclonus, ataxia, and other neurological signs. While behavioral changes can occur, urinary incontinence and multiple falls are not typical presenting features of CJD.

questions.text: Which type of aphasia is seen in the lesions of the posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Fluent

Explanation: Lesion of the posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus indicates Wernicke's aphasia. This condition is characterized by fluent speech.

 

Feature

Wernicke's Aphasia

Broca's Aphasia (Option B)

Global Aphasia

Conduction Aphasia (Option D)

Speech Output

Fluent, but paraphasic and circumlocutious, jargon speech

Nonfluent, labored, dysarthric, telegraphic

Nonfluent, severely impaired

Fluent, but many phonemic paraphasias

Comprehension

Impaired for spoken and written words

Intact, except for syntactically complex sentences

Severely impaired

Intact for spoken language, impaired for reading aloud

Repetition

Impaired

Impaired

Severely impaired

Severely impaired, with phonemic paraphasias

Naming

Impaired, leading to neologisms

Impaired

Severely impaired

Impaired, with phonemic paraphasias

Writing

Impaired

Impaired

Severely impaired

Impaired, with phonemic paraphasias

Motor Output (Facial and Limb)

Often unremarkable (rare mild facial flattening)

Right facial weakness, hemiparesis, buccofacial apraxia

Right hemiplegia, hemisensory loss

Varies depending on lesion site

Cause (Common Lesions)

Posterior part of superior temporal gyrus, inferior MCA branches

Inferior frontal gyrus, superior MCA branches

Involves entire MCA distribution

Arcuate fasciculus, MCA branches

Associated Features

Severe agitation, paranoia, possible right hemianopia

Right facial weakness, hemiparesis, emotional distress

Right hemiplegia, hemisensory loss, homonymous hemianopia

No significant associated features

Anomic (Option C) aphasia is associated with lesions in areas such as the left temporal/ occipital lesions (area 37) and left thalamus, which disrupt the brain's ability to access words, especially nouns and verbs. This results in difficulty finding words, although comprehension and fluency are generally preserved.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male was brought to the emergency room with a history of RTA. GCS progressively declines over hours and axial T2 MRI shows multiple small hypointense lesions at the corticomedullary junction and basal ganglia. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Diffuse axonal injury

Explanation:

  • Diffuse axonal injury (DAI) is a form of traumatic brain injury caused by a blunt force injury to the brain, often from high-speed motor vehicle accidents.

Aetiology:

  • Cause: High-speed accidents, where accelerating and decelerating forces cause shearing of axons in the white matter of the brain.
  • Affected Areas: Primarily the corpus callosum, brainstem, and white matter tracts, especially at the junction of grey and white matter.

Pathophysiology:

  • Shearing forces disrupt neuronal connections, leading to brain dysfunction.
  • Common Deficits: Affect frontal and temporal white matter, corpus callosum, and brainstem.

Clinical Presentation:

  • Diagnosis: Clinical diagnosis, typically with a GCS of less than 8 lasting over six hours.
  • Symptoms:
    • Mild: Headache, dizziness, nausea, and fatigue.
    • Severe: Loss of consciousness, persistent vegetative state, potential long-term recovery for a few.
    • Dysautonomia: Tachycardia, tachypnea, hyperthermia, abnormal muscle tone, and posturing.

Evaluation:

  • CT: Small punctate haemorrhages to white matter tracts.
  • MRI: Investigation of choice
    • Small areas of cerebral microbleeds at the grey-white matter junction, corpus callosum, or the brainstem.

Treatment/Management:

  • Goals: Prevent secondary injuries (e.g., hypoxia, hypotension, intracranial hypertension) and support recovery.
  • Initial Treatment: Focus on stabilization, including resuscitation and prevention of complications like cerebral oedema and elevated ICP.
  • ICP Monitoring: Recommended for GCS below 8 and for patients unable to be regularly evaluated neurologically.
  • Anticonvulsants: Short-term use (7 days) to prevent early seizures.
  • Emerging Therapies: Progesterone treatment shows promise but cannot be routinely recommended.

Incorrect Options:

Extensive subarachnoid haemorrhage (Option B) is a life-threatening condition due to the accumulation of blood between the arachnoid and pia mater.

Hypoxic cerebral injury (Option C) refers to injury of the brain due to a lack of oxygen delivery enough to support metabolic needs. This is caused due to conditions like cardiac arrest, strangulation, severe anaemia, systemic hypotension, etc.

Multiple hemorrhagic contusions (Option D) are traumatic brain injuries which are the most disabling type of traumatic phenomenon. These can be caused by falls, road traffic accidents, aggression, sports injuries, cyclists, etc. These appear as several localized areas of bleeding.

questions.text: Visual field testing of a patient revealed the following type of loss. Where is the likely site of lesion in the optic pathway?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Occipital lobe

Explanation:

  • A lesion in the occipital lobe, specifically in the Posterior Cerebral Artery (PCA) territory affecting the calcarine cortex, typically causes congruous homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing.
  • This characteristic defect arises because the posterior cerebral artery (PCA) is the major artery supplying the primary visual cortex, while the macula is protected by its blood supply from the middle cerebral artery (MCA).

Lesions in Visual Cortex:

  • Typically present as congruous homonymous hemianopia (visual field loss is consistent in both eyes).

Visual Pathway Lesions and Defects

Site of Lesion

Fibers Affected

Field Defect

Optic Nerve

Ipsilateral Temporal + Nasal Fibers

Anopia

Optic Chiasma

(Option D)

Bilateral Nasal Fibers

Bitemporal Hemianopia

(Heteronymous Hemianopia)
  • Optic Tract
  • Lateral Geniculate Body (LGB Lesion)
  • Optic Radiation (Option C)

Ipsilateral Temporal Fibers + Contralateral Nasal Fibers

Homonymous Hemianopia

Visual Cortex without the involvement of tip

(Post. Cerebral Artery)

Ipsilateral Temporal Fibers + Contralateral Nasal Fibers except for macular representation

Homonymous Hemianopia with Macular Sparing

Tip of Visual Cortex

(Middle Cerebral Artery)

Macular Representation of Ipsilateral Temporal and Contralateral Nasal Fibers.

Macular Homonymous Hemianopia


The frontal visual field (Option A) is incorrect since a lesion in this area affects functions like attention, visual scanning, and decision-making. The image in the given scenario is not associated with this area.

questions.text: What is the most probable cause for a 22-year-old man who has a high-grade fever, a purpuric rash, and a CSF sample showing gram-negative diplococci?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Neisseria meningitidis

Explanation:

The above image is that of a purpuric rash which is seen in meningococcemia caused by Neisseria meningitides.

  • Neisseria meningitidis is a gram negative diplococci.
  • Fulminant meningococcemia presents with a very high fever and hemorrhagic rash.

Acute Bacterial Meningitis

  • Definition: Acute purulent infection in the subarachnoid space (SAS) leading to CNS inflammation.
  • Causes:
    • Streptococcus pneumoniae and Neisseria meningitides are the primary causes.
    • Listeria monocytogenes is a significant risk in adults over 50, especially in those with diabetes, alcoholism, or weakened immune systems.
  • Presentation: Can be acute and fulminant or subacute, with the classic triad of symptoms:
    • Fever
    • Headache
    • Nuchal rigidity (stiff neck)

Clinical features

Description

Consciousness

Decreased level of consciousness occurs in >75% of cases, ranging from lethargy to coma.

Kernig's Sign

Positive when passive extension of the knee elicits pain; indicative of meningeal irritation.

Brudzinski's Sign

Positive when passive flexion of the neck results in spontaneous flexion of the hips and knees; also indicative of meningeal irritation.

Pupils

May present as dilated and poorly reactive due to increased intracranial pressure (ICP).

Posturing

Possible decerebrate posturing as a sign of severe CNS dysfunction.

Signs of Increased ICP

Includes elevated CSF opening pressure (>180 mmH2O), papilledema, and potential cerebral herniation (1–8% incidence).

Additional Symptoms

Nausea, vomiting, photophobia; seizures in 15–40% (focal or generalized).

Meningococcemia Rash

Erythematous maculopapular rash that quickly becomes petechial, commonly on the trunk and lower extremities.

 

Pseudomonas aeruginosa (Option B) is a gram-negative rod-shaped bacteria.

Streptococcus pneumoniae (Option C) is a gram-positive, spherical bacteria.

E. Coli (Option D) is a gram-negative rod-shaped bacteria.

questions.text: A 72-year-old former pilot visits a neurologist, accompanied by his wife, exhibiting symptoms of rapidly advancing dementia, myoclonus, ataxia, and visual impairments. The provided FLAIR MRI scans can assist in confirming the diagnosis. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Variant CJD

Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario and the FLAIR MRI in the scenario showing the “hockey stick” sign is found in variant type Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD).
  • Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease (CJD) is a rare, rapidly progressing brain disorder affecting coordination, memory, and mental functions.

Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) findings

 

 

 

 

 

Electroencephalography (EEG)
  • Periodic sharp wave complexes (PSWC)
  • These can be either lateralized in earlier stages or generalized in later stages.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

MRI findings
  • DWI or FLAIR MRI has a sensitivity of 98% and specificity of 93%
  • DWI: Increased intensity in the basal ganglia, thalamus, and cortex
  • Cortical ribboning
  • Hockey stick or pulvinar sign is seen in variant, infectious, or acquired CJD

 

In the initial stages, the MRI is normal in Alzheimer’s (Option A), and in the later stages shows temporal and parietal atrophy.

There is no history of stroke; hence vascular dementia (Option B) is unlikely to be the diagnosis

The hockey stick sign is not and indicator of sporadic CJD (Option C).

questions.text: A patient was asked to copy the face of a clock and his drawing is shown below. What is the correct term to be used here?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hemispatial neglect

Explanation:

  • The given image represents the patient suffering from hemispatial neglect where there are missing details in the left side of the line drawing.

Hemispatial Neglect:

  • Hemispatial neglect is the inability to report, respond, and orient to stimuli in one-half of the space despite having no motor or sensory deficits.

Types and location of lesions:

  • Contralesional Hemispatial Neglect:
    • Result of damage to cortical or subcortical components of the spatial attention network.
    • Not always caused by parietal lobe lesions, as traditionally believed.
  • Spatial Attention Model:
    • Right hemisphere: Directs attention to the entire extrapersonal space.
    • Left hemisphere: Directs attention mostly to the right hemispace (contralateral).
    • Left hemisphere lesions: Minor neglect, as the right hemisphere compensates.
    • Right hemisphere lesions: Severe neglect of the left hemispace due to lack of ipsilateral attentional mechanisms in the left hemisphere.

Clinical Examination:

  • Patients may neglect grooming, eating, and reading on the left side.
  • Line drawing and writing often have missing details on the left side.
  • Tests for neglect:
    • Simultaneous Bilateral Stimulation: Patients fail to detect bilateral stimuli and experience extinction (only detecting stimuli from the right side).
    • Target Detection Task: Difficulty detecting targets on the left side, reflecting a motor and attentional deficit rather than sensory input loss (hemianopia).
  • Some patients may deny the existence of hemiparesis or even the paralyzed limb (anosognosia).

Clinical Observation:

  • Neglect is more common, severe, and long-lasting after right hemisphere damage.
  • Severe neglect of the right hemispace is rare even with left hemisphere lesions.

 

Confabulation (Option A) is a phenomenon in which the patient fills in memory gaps with made-up stories and inaccurate facts.

Kinetic apraxia (Option C) is the inability to perform a fine movement or task despite having the desire and physical capability to do it. The lesion lies in the paracentral cortex.

Asterixis (Option D) is a type of negative myoclonus where irregular lapses of the posture of body parts are noted.

questions.text: A patient who is 66 years old and has a history of chronic hypertension, arrives at the emergency room with changes in mental state and high blood pressure measuring 210/110 mm Hg. A brain CT scan shows bleeding within the brain tissue. The typical location of this bleeding in similar cases is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Putamen

Explanation:

The features are of intraparenchymal hemorrhage due to hypertension which occurs in the deep tissues of the brain. The most common site of this is putamen.

  • The sudden elevation in blood pressure can overwhelm cerebral autoregulation
  • Most commonly affects small penetrating arteries (lenticulostriate arteries)

Common causes of intracerebral haemorrhage include:

  • Hypertension (most common - affecting basal ganglia, thalamus, pons, cerebellum)
  • Drug use (cocaine, methamphetamine) - especially in young patients
  • Cerebral amyloid angiopathy (elderly, lobar haemorrhages)
  • Coagulopathy
  • Vascular malformations
  • Head trauma
  • Hemorrhagic transformation of ischemic stroke

Direct vessel wall damage:

  • While cocaine can cause endothelial dysfunction over time
  • Direct vessel wall damage is more associated with chronic use
  • Acute haemorrhage is primarily due to pressure effects
  • More relevant in chronic vasculopathy

Vasculitis:

  • This can occur with chronic cocaine use
  • Usually presents with multiple vascular territories
  • More commonly causes ischemic events
  • Takes time to develop and isn't the acute mechanism

Amyloid deposition:

  • Typically occurs in the elderly (>60 years)
  • Associated with lobar haemorrhages
  • Caused by β-amyloid deposition in vessel walls

Feature

Cerebral Amyloid

Angiopathy (CAA)

Berry Aneurysm Rupture

Hypertensive Crisis

Venous Sinus Thrombosis

Age Group

Elderly (>60 years)

Younger

Older, with chronic HTN

Younger, hypercoagulable states

Hypertension

None

None

Chronic HTN

None

Hemorrhage Type

Multiple lobar haemorrhages

Subarachnoid, single-event

Deep (e.g., putamen, thalamus)

Hemorrhagic infarction

Hemorrhage Location

Cortical-subcortical regions

Subarachnoid space

Deep brain structures

Venous infarction

Imaging

Lobar haemorrhages, microbleeds

Single, subarachnoid bleed

Deep hemorrhage

Venous infarction pattern

Symptoms

Acute neurological symptoms

Thunderclap headache

Often no symptoms

Seizures, focal deficits

Onset

Acute neurological presentation

Sudden, thunderclap headache

Acute, with chronic HTN

Acute, gradual progression

Distribution

Spares deep structures

Focal

Deep brain

Venous infarction

While intraparenchymal haemorrhage can occur in other brain regions, such as the thalamus (Option B), pons (Option C), or cerebellum (Option D), the putamen is the most commonly affected site in cases of chronic hypertension-associated haemorrhage.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents with weakness in right arm for 6 hours. The weakness gradually became lesser and later resolved. She is a known case of diabetes and hypertension and is obese. Which of the following is the probable diagnosis of this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Transient ischaemic attack

Explanation:

  • Based on the given clinical presentation, the probable diagnosis in this case is Transient Ischaemic Attack (TIA).

Transient Ischaemic Attack (TIA)

  • Defined as a transient episode of neurologic dysfunction due to the focal brain, spinal cord, or retinal ischemia without acute infarction or tissue injury.
  • A TIA typically lasts less than an hour, more often minutes.
  • Usually resolves within 24 hours.
  • Risk is highest in the first 48 hours following a transient ischemic attack.

Etiology:

  • Common risk factors for all TIA include diabetes, hypertension, age, smoking, obesity, alcoholism, unhealthy diet, psychosocial stress, and lack of regular physical activity.
  • A previous history of stroke or TIA will increase substantially the subsequent risk of recurrent stroke or TIA.

Pathophysiology:

TIA subtypes, classified according to the pathophysiological mechanisms

  • Large artery atherothrombosis (M/C): This may be intracranial or extracranial atherothrombosis. The mechanism may be a lack of blood flow distal to the site of arterial stenosis or an artery-to-artery embolism.
  • Small vessel ischemic diseases: The underlying pathology is either lipohyalinosis or small vessel arteriolosclerosis. The commonest risk factor is hypertension, followed by diabetes and age.
  • Cardiac embolism: A clot in the cardiac chamber, most commonly in the left atrium, is secondary to atrial fibrillation.
  • Cryptogenic: This is usually a cortical pattern of ischemia without any identifiable large artery atherothrombosis or cardiac source of emboli. More recently it is often referred to as ESUS (embolic stroke of unknown source).
  • Other uncommon causes such as arterial dissection or vasculitis.

ABCD2 Score for TIA (Transient Ischemic Attack): The Risk of Stroke

Parameter

Criteria

Points

Age

> 60 years

1 point

Blood Pressure

BP ≥ 140/90

1 point

Clinical Features

Speech disturbance without weakness

1 point

Unilateral weakness

2 points

Duration

10–59 minutes

1 point

≥ 60 minutes

2 points

Diabetes

Presence of diabetes

1 point

 

Stroke Risk Based on Score:

Score

Stroke Risk

Day 2

Day 7

Day 90

1%

4.1%

Compressive neuropathy typically (Option A) results in persistent symptoms rather than transient symptoms as described in the case.

Ischaemic stroke (Option C) involves a more prolonged disruption of blood flow to a specific area of the brain, leading to persistent neurological deficits that do not resolve within 24 hours.

Diabetic neuropathy (Option D) is unlikely to cause transient weakness limited to one side of the body, as seen in this case.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about tremors are true?


	PD is characterized by resting tremor
	Tremor consist of alternate contraction of agonist and antagonist muscle in an oscillating rhythmic manner
	Essential tremor is an uncommon movement disorder.
	Normal individuals can have physiologic tremors that manifest as mild high frequency, postural or action tremors
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 1,2,4 only

Explanation:

Essential tremor is the most common movement disorder, affecting approximately 5-10% of the general population, with increasing prevalence in older age groups. It usually presents as a bilateral postural 6 to 12 Hz tremor of the hands and head. The Movement Disorders Society diagnostic criteria include:

  • Tremor is bilateral, symmetrical, and postural
  • The tremor involves the forearms and hand
  • Is persistent and visible
  • It may be associated with isolated head tremor

Causes and characteristics of tremors

Type of Tremor

Cause

Characteristics

Exacerbating Factors

Alleviating Factors

Resting Tremor

Parkinson's disease
  • Occurs at rest
  • Pill-rolling movement
  • Asymmetrical
  • Emotional stress
  • Fatigue

Voluntary movement

Action Tremor
  • Cerebellar disorders
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • Tremor occurs with voluntary movement
  • Intention tremor (worsens near target)

Movement initiation

Rest

Postural Tremor
  • Essential tremor
  • Physiologic tremor
  • Tremor when maintaining posture against gravity
  • Fine or coarse oscillations
  • Anxiety
  • Fatigue
  • Caffeine
  • Alcohol
  • Beta-blockers

Intention Tremor

Cerebellar damage

Increases in amplitude as the target is approached

Goal-directed movements

Rest

Physiologic Tremor

Normal individuals

Fine, rapid, low-amplitude tremor
  • Anxiety
  • Caffeine
  • Hyperthyroidism
  • Rest
  • Sleep

Essential Tremor (Most Common Tremors)

Unknown (often familial)
  • Bilateral, symmetric
  • Affects hands, head, voice
  • Stress
  • Fatigue
  • Alcohol
  • Beta-blockers

Dystonic Tremor

Dystonia
  • Irregular tremor
  • Associated with abnormal postures

Movement or sustained posture

Sensory tricks (geste antagonists)

Drug-induced Tremor
  • Lithium
  • Valproate
  • SSRIs
  • Symmetric, postural, or action tremor

Drug use

Dose reduction or discontinuation

Psychogenic Tremor

Functional neurologic disorder
  • Sudden onset
  • Inconsistent tremor
  • Disappears with distraction

Psychological stress
  • Distraction
  • Psychotherapy

 

Parkinson's Disease (PD) is characterized by a classic resting tremor (Statement 1 Ruled Out) which occurs at rest and decreases with intentional movement.

Tremor physiology involves the alternating contraction of opposing muscle groups (agonist and antagonist) in a rhythmic pattern. (Statement 2 Ruled Out)

Physiologic tremors are a normal phenomenon that can occur in healthy individuals, particularly during certain postures or actions. (Statement 4 Ruled Out)

Statement 3 regarding essential tremor being uncommon and affecting 5% of the population is incorrect.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most important pathophysiological mechanism for Berry aneurysm?

choices.text: Endothelial injury of vessel due to HTN
Muscle intimal elastic lamina layer defect

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Muscle intimal elastic lamina layer defect

Explanation:

  • Berry aneurysms primarily develop due to disruption of the internal elastic lamina of cerebral blood vessels. The internal elastic lamina is a critical structural component that provides tensile strength and elasticity to blood vessels. When this layer is compromised, the vessel wall becomes weakened and less able to withstand normal hemodynamic stresses, leading to outward bulging and eventual aneurysm formation.

Berry Aneurysm

Definition
  • Saccular outpouching of intracranial arterial wall
  • Represents 90% of cerebral aneurysms
  • Primary location: Circle of Willis
  • Most common sites:
    • Anterior communicating/anterior cerebral junction
    • Posterior communicating/internal carotid junction
    • Middle cerebral artery bifurcation
    • Basilar apex

Pathophysiological Mechanisms

Structural Changes:

  • Most important- Internal elastic lamina disruption
  • Media layer thinning
  • Adventitial layer remodeling

Molecular Mechanisms:

  • Inflammatory mediator activation
  • Matrix metalloproteinase upregulation
  • Vessel wall extracellular matrix degradation

Hemodynamic Factors:

  • Wall shear stress elevation
  • Flow-related endothelial injury
  • Intramural stress distribution alterations

Histopathological Classification

1. Mycotic:

  • Infectious arterial wall damage
  • Distal vessel predilection
  • Inflammatory cell infiltration

2. Arteriosclerotic:

  • Intimal hyperplasia
  • Media degeneration
  • Elastic fiber fragmentation

3. Traumatic:

  • Transmural disruption
  • False lumen formation
  • Adventitial hemorrhage

Rupture Risk Stratification

Morphological Criteria:

  • Size >7mm: high risk
  • Aspect ratio >1.6
  • Daughter sac presence
  • Wall irregularity

Hemodynamic Factors:

  • Systolic BP >140 mmHg
  • Flow pattern alterations
  • Intrasaccular pressure gradients

Genetic Markers:

  • Collagen deficiency
  • Elastic fiber abnormalities
  • Matrix metalloproteinase polymorphisms

Clinical Manifestations

Subarachnoid Hemorrhage:

  • Hunt-Hess grading scale correlation
  • Fisher scale for CT findings
  • Modified Rankin Scale outcomes

Mass Effect:

  • Cranial nerve compression syndromes
  • Brainstem compression sequelae
  • Hydrocephalus development

Thromboembolic Events:

  • Watershed infarction patterns
  • Perforator occlusion syndromes
  • Distal embolization phenomena

 

Endothelial injury due to HTN (Option A) while hypertension can exacerbate aneurysm formation and increase rupture risk, it is not the primary underlying cause of berry aneurysms. Hypertension acts as a contributing factor rather than the initiating defect.

Endothelial layer defect (Option C) although the endothelium can be involved in aneurysm progression, the primary defect occurs in the internal elastic lamina rather than the endothelial layer. The endothelial dysfunction is usually secondary to the underlying structural abnormality.

Adventitia defect (Option D) the adventitial layer is the outer layer of blood vessels and is not the primary site of berry aneurysm formation. The key pathology begins in the internal elastic lamina and medial layer of the vessel wall.

questions.text: A 16 year old girl, who is taking antiepileptics, has had a seizure-free period of 6 months. She has no family history of epilepsy. Her EEG is now normal and she has a normal neurological exam and intelligence. What would be your advice?

choices.text: Stop the treatment and follow up
Gradually taper the drug and stop treatment

questions.solution:
Correct option:

Option c: Continue treatment for another 2 years: This option is correct. The recommended approach in this scenario is to continue treatment for another 2 years. The duration of seizure freedom required before considering discontinuation of antiepileptic drugs varies, but typically 2-5 years of seizure freedom is considered an appropriate period.

 

Incorrect Option:

Option a. Stop the treatment and follow up: This option is incorrect. The 16-year-old girl has been seizure-free for 6 months, but it does not necessarily mean that she can safely stop the treatment altogether. Stopping the treatment abruptly can increase the risk of seizure recurrence.

Option b. Gradually taper the drug and stop treatment: This option is incorrect. While the girl has been seizure-free for 6 months, it is generally recommended to continue treatment for a longer period before considering tapering and stopping the antiepileptic drug. Gradual tapering of the drug under medical supervision may be considered later, but not at this stage.

Optiond. Continue lifelong treatment with antiepileptics: This option is incorrect. Lifelong treatment with antiepileptic drugs is not necessary in all cases. If the girl remains seizure-free for a prolonged period (usually 2-5 years), there may be an opportunity to gradually taper and discontinue the medication under medical supervision.

questions.text: Which of the following is one of the earliest presenting symptoms in a patient with Multiple Sclerosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A. Sensory disturbances

Explanation:

  • Sensory disturbances such as paresthesias (tingling, “pins and needles”), hypesthesia (numbness), and dysesthetic sensations (e.g., burning, swelling, tight wrapping) are among the most common and earliest symptoms in MS.
  • They reflect demyelination in the sensory pathways and can appear abruptly or insidiously.

Multiple sclerosis (MS) Clinical features:

  • Abrupt or insidious onset of symptoms

Sensory symptoms
  • Paresthesias: tingling, prickling sensations, “pins and needles,” or painful burning.
  • Hypesthesia: reduced sensation, numbness, or a “dead” feeling.
  • Unpleasant sensations: feelings that body parts are swollen, wet, raw, or tightly wrapped.
  • Pain is a common symptom of MS.

Optic neuritis (ON) (Option C ruled out)
  • Diminished visual acuity.
  • Decreased colour perception in the central field of vision.
  • May progress to severe visual loss.
  • Periorbital pain.
  • Fundoscopic examination: normal or optic disc swelling (papillitis), pallor of the optic disc (optic atrophy).

Weakness of the limbs
  • Loss of strength, speed, dexterity, and gait disturbance.
  • Exercise-induced weakness is a characteristic symptom of MS.
  • Upper motor neuron type weakness accompanied by other pyramidal signs.

Facial weakness
  • Lesion in the pons may resemble idiopathic Bell’s palsy.

Spasticity
  • Spontaneous and movement-induced muscle spasms.
  • Painful spasms.

Visual blurring
  • Due to ON (optic neuritis) or diplopia.
  • Diplopia is caused by internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO) or palsy of the sixth cranial nerve. (Option D ruled out)
  • Bilateral INO is particularly suggestive of MS.
  • Other gaze disturbances in MS:
    • Horizontal gaze palsy
    • One-and-a-half syndrome (horizontal gaze palsy plus an INO)
    • Acquired pendular nystagmus

Ataxia
  • Cerebellar tremors.
  • Cerebellar dysarthria.

Vertigo
  • Lesion in the brainstem.

 

Ancillary symptoms

Paroxysmal symptoms

Brief duration (10s to 2 min), high frequency (5–40 episodes per day), no change of consciousness or change in background electroencephalogram during episodes, and a self-limited course.

Lhermitte’s symptom (Option A ruled out)

An electric shock-like sensation that radiates down the back into the legs.

Typically induced by flexion or other movements of the neck.

Trigeminal neuralgia, hemifacial spasm, and glossopharyngeal neuralgia

Demyelinating lesions involve the root entry or exit zone of the fifth, seventh, and ninth cranial nerve, respectively.

Facial myokymia

Persistent rapid flickering contractions of the facial musculature

Slow spread of contraction across the face.

Heat sensitivity

Uthoff symptoms: Neurological symptoms develop from heat exposure, such as steam baths and saunas.

Bladder dysfunction

Present in >90% of MS patients.

Detrusor hyperreflexia.

Detrusor sphincter dyssynergia - hesitancy, urinary retention, overflow incontinence, and recurrent infection.

Bowel dysfunction

Constipation, faecal urgency or bowel incontinence.

Cognitive dysfunction

Memory loss.

Impaired attention.

Psychiatric symptom

Depression.

Fatigue

90% of patients experience fatigue.

It causes work-related disability.

Incorrect Options:

Ataxia (Option B): Usually appears later due to cerebellar involvement, not a common early symptom.

Vertigo (Option C): Caused by brainstem lesions, but not an early presenting symptom in MS.
Facial palsy (Option D): Results from pontine lesions, but is rare as an initial symptom.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents with severe headache, vomiting & photophobia. On examination, neck rigidity and Brudzinski's sign are positive. A CT scan of the brain shows hydrocephalus and no haemorrhage. CSF examination is normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Subarachnoid Haemorrhage

Explanation:

  • SAH often presents with sudden severe headache, vomiting, photophobia, and meningeal signs. CT may miss early or small bleeds, and CSF can be normal if bleeding is minimal or delayed. Hydrocephalus suggests impaired CSF drainage due to subarachnoid blood.

Subarachnoid hemorrhage
  • Subarachnoid Hemorrhage (SAH): Blood accumulation in the subarachnoid space.
  • Causes: Often due to aneurysm rupture (~85%) or trauma.
  • Non-traumatic SAH is most commonly caused by the rupture of a saccular aneurysm.
  • Clinical Impact: High mortality and morbidity; often presents with a sudden, severe headache (worst headache of life).
  • Complications: Seizures, vasospasm, hydrocephalus, and delayed cerebral ischemia (DCI).

Epidemiology:

  • Age/ Gender: Most of the SAH occurs between age of 40-60, mean rupture age 50-55 and slightly more prevalent in females.
  • Risk Factors: Smoking and history of ruptured aneurysms increase SAH risk.

Etiology:

  • Aneurysmal SAH (aSAH):
    • Risk Factors: Hypertension, smoking, family history, alcohol use, sympathomimetic drugs, and estrogen deficiency.
    • Rupture Risk: (Option D)
      • Age >60
      • Posterior circulation aneurysms
      • Atherosclerosis
      • Aneurysm size
        • Aneurysms <10 mm: ~0.1% annual rupture risk.
        • Aneurysms ≥10 mm: 0.5–1% annual rupture risk.
        • Giant aneurysms (>2.5 cm): ~6% rupture risk in first year.
      • Family history
      • Previous SAH
      • ADPKD
  • Nonaneurysmal SAH (NASAH):
    • Perimesencephalic NASAH: Localized blood in perimesencephalic cisterns, normal angiography, benign course.
    • Occult Aneurysm: Small aneurysms missed on initial angiography, detectable on repeat imaging.
    • Vascular Malformations: Includes arteriovenous malformations (AVM) and dural arteriovenous fistulae. Treated with surgery or endovascular interventions.
    • Intracranial Arterial Dissection: Diagnosed by angiography, causes severe bleeding, treated with surgery or endovascular methods.
    • Other Causes: Cocaine abuse, cerebral amyloid angiopathy, cerebral venous thrombosis, sickle cell disorders, moyamoya disease, cerebral vasculitis, bleeding disorders.

Pathophysiology:

  • Hemodynamic Stress: Central to intracranial aneurysm formation, especially at arterial bifurcations.
  • Aneurysm Rupture: Causes neurological damage through compression of adjacent brain tissue and ischemia from reduced blood flow.
    • Mechanisms: Hemodynamic stress and inflammation (matrix metalloproteinase (MMP)-mediated degradation of extracellular matrix) weaken the arterial wall, promoting aneurysm formation and rupture.
    • Inflammatory Response: Macrophages and smooth muscle cells drive these degenerative processes.

Clinical features:

  • Sudden, severe "thunderclap" headache (hallmark)
  • Loss of consciousness: Increase in intracranial pressure.
    • It presses the reticular activating system.
    • Leads to the development of stupor and coma.
  • Worst headache of the life
  • Nuchal rigidity is due to blood but no fever.
  • Vomiting
  • Sentinel bleed: microbleeds from the berry Aneurysm

Investigations:

  • Non-contrast CT head: "Hyperdense" blood in the subarachnoid space ("SAH star")
  • Lumbar puncture: Xanthochromia (yellowish discoloration) of CSF after 12 hours
  • Cerebral angiography: Identifies aneurysms or AVMs
  • CT angiography or MR angiography: Non-invasive methods to detect vascular abnormalities

Incorrect Options:

Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus (NPH) (Option A): Presents with triad: dementia, gait disturbance, urinary incontinence—not acute meningeal symptoms.

Bacterial Meningitis (Option B): Would show abnormal CSF: high protein, low glucose, and neutrophilic pleocytosis.

Viral Encephalitis (Option C): Presents with altered sensorium, seizures, and abnormal CSF (lymphocytic pleocytosis), not just headache and normal CSF.

questions.text: A 65-year-old known case of Parkinson's disease presents with oropharyngeal dysphagia and recurrent episodes of aspiration pneumonitis, complaints of excessive respiratory secretions. Chest imaging reveals bilateral bronchiectasis. What is the most appropriate long-term management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: Option C. PEG (Percutaneous Endoscopic Gastrostomy) tube

Explanation:

  • In Parkinson's disease, oropharyngeal dysphagia is common due to impaired coordination of swallowing muscles. This leads to aspiration of food, liquids, and saliva, resulting in recurrent pneumonitis and long-term complications like bronchiectasis.
  • PEG (Percutaneous Endoscopic Gastrostomy) tube helps bypass the oropharyngeal route for nutrition, reducing the risk of aspiration pneumonia and supporting nutritional status. It serves as a long-term management strategy that directly addresses the underlying cause—oropharyngeal dysfunction and aspiration.

Incorrect Options:

High-frequency chest wall oscillation therapy (Option A) is useful in conditions like cystic fibrosis or bronchiectasis to help clear mucus, but it does not address aspiration or dysphagia, which are the primary issues in this patient.

Nebulized N-acetylcysteine (NAC) (Option B) may help thin mucus, but it can irritate the airways and potentially increase secretions, without addressing the core problem of aspiration.

Macrolide therapy (Option D) can be used in non-CF bronchiectasis for its anti-inflammatory effects; however, it targets only secondary inflammation and not the primary issue of aspiration.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Multiple Sclerosis (MS) is incorrect?

choices.text: 70% of patients with MS develop optic neuritis during course of illness
Oral steroids are given for acute relapses
Loss of color perception and depth perception is proportional to visual loss
Examination of fundus can be normal and can show papillitis

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Loss of color perception and depth perception is proportional to visual loss

Explanation:

  • In optic neuritis (often seen in MS), color vision (especially red) and depth perception can be disproportionately affected compared to overall visual acuity. A patient may have mild visual acuity loss but significant dyschromatopsia (color desaturation) or depth perception difficulties.

Multiple sclerosis (MS) Clinical features:

  • Abrupt or insidious onset of symptoms

Sensory symptoms
  • Paresthesias: tingling, prickling sensations, “pins and needles,” or painful burning.
  • Hypesthesia: reduced sensation, numbness, or a “dead” feeling.
  • Unpleasant sensations: feelings that body parts are swollen, wet, raw, or tightly wrapped.
  • Pain is a common symptom of MS.

Optic neuritis (ON)

  • Diminished visual acuity.
  • Decreased colour perception in the central field of vision.
  • May progress to severe visual loss.
  • Periorbital pain.
  • Fundoscopic examination: normal or optic disc swelling (papillitis), pallor of the optic disc (optic atrophy).

Weakness of the limbs
  • Loss of strength, speed, dexterity, and gait disturbance.
  • Exercise-induced weakness is a characteristic symptom of MS.
  • Upper motor neuron type weakness accompanied by other pyramidal signs.

Facial weakness
  • Lesion in the pons may resemble idiopathic Bell’s palsy.

Spasticity
  • Spontaneous and movement-induced muscle spasms.
  • Painful spasms.

Visual blurring
  • Due to ON (optic neuritis) or diplopia.
  • Diplopia is caused by internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO) or palsy of the sixth cranial nerve.
  • Bilateral INO is particularly suggestive of MS.
  • Other gaze disturbances in MS:
    • Horizontal gaze palsy
    • One-and-a-half syndrome (horizontal gaze palsy plus an INO)
    • Acquired pendular nystagmus

Ataxia
  • Cerebellar tremors.
  • Cerebellar dysarthria.

Vertigo
  • Lesion in the brainstem.

 

Ancillary symptoms

Paroxysmal symptoms

Brief duration (10s to 2 min), high frequency (5–40 episodes per day), no change of consciousness or change in background electroencephalogram during episodes, and a self-limited course.

Lhermitte’s symptom

An electric shock-like sensation that radiates down the back into the legs.

Typically induced by flexion or other movements of the neck.

Trigeminal neuralgia, hemifacial spasm, and glossopharyngeal neuralgia

Demyelinating lesions involve the root entry or exit zone of the fifth, seventh, and ninth cranial nerve, respectively.

Facial myokymia

Persistent rapid flickering contractions of the facial musculature

Slow spread of contraction across the face.

Heat sensitivity

Uthoff symptoms: Neurological symptoms develop from heat exposure, such as steam baths and saunas.

Bladder dysfunction

Present in >90% of MS patients.

Detrusor hyperreflexia.

Detrusor sphincter dyssynergia - hesitancy, urinary retention, overflow incontinence, and recurrent infection.

Bowel dysfunction

Constipation, faecal urgency or bowel incontinence.

Cognitive dysfunction

Memory loss.

Impaired attention.

Psychiatric symptom

Depression.

Fatigue

90% of patients experience fatigue.

It causes work-related disability.

Incorrect Options:

70% of patients with MS develop optic neuritis during course of illness (Option A): Optic neuritis is a common presenting symptom and complication of MS. Around 70% of patients develop it at some point during the disease. It often causes painful vision loss, especially on eye movement.

Oral steroids are given for acute relapses (Option B): High-dose intravenous steroids (e.g., methylprednisolone) are preferred for acute relapses, but oral steroids (like oral prednisolone or tapering doses after IV) can also be used in certain cases. So, oral steroids are indeed part of acute relapse management, especially during recovery or tapering phases.

Examination of fundus can be normal and can show papillitis (Option D): In optic neuritis, retrobulbar neuritis often shows a normal fundus because the inflammation is behind the globe. However, in some cases, papillitis (optic disc swelling) may be seen. Both scenarios are possible in MS-related optic neuritis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female with seizures was prescribed carbamazepine & erythromycin. A few days later, she developed ataxia. What is the most likely cause of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Carbamazepine toxicity

Explanation:

Erythromycin inhibits CYP3A4, the enzyme that metabolizes Carbamazepine, leading to elevated carbamazepine levels and resulting in toxicity, with ataxia being a common symptom.

  • MOA: Inhibits high-frequency neuronal discharges and modulates voltage-gated sodium channels.
  • Uses:
    • Trigeminal neuralgia
    • GTCS (generalized tonic clonic seizures)
    • Partial seizures
    • Bipolar disorder.
  • Interactions:
    • Metabolism of carbamazepine is induced by phenobarbitone, phenytoin, and vice versa.
    • Erythromycin, fluoxetine, and isoniazid inhibit the metabolism of carbamazepine. (Option A)

Adverse Effects

Description

Neurotoxicity

Sedation, dizziness, vertigo, diplopia, and ataxia

Gastrointestinal Effects

Vomiting and diarrhoea occur with higher doses.

Acute Intoxication

Coma, convulsions, cardiovascular collapse.

Haematological

Agranulocytosis, aplastic anaemia.

Hypersensitivity Reactions

Rashes, photosensitivity, hepatitis, lupus-like syndrome.

Water Retention and Hyponatremia

Due to enhanced antidiuretic hormone (ADH) action, it is more common in the elderly.

Teratogenicity

Increased incidence of minor fetal malformations.

Incorrect Options:

Erythromycin toxicity (Option B) is not the cause, as it rarely causes ataxia. Its main role here is as a CYP3A4 inhibitor, which increases carbamazepine levels and leads to toxicity.

Worsening of the underlying disease (Option C) can cause ataxia, but the timing after starting erythromycin points to a drug interaction, making this less likely.

A separate, unrelated neurological condition (Option D) is unlikely, as the timing with carbamazepine and erythromycin use suggests a drug interaction rather than a new, unrelated diagnosis.

questions.text: A young female presents with ptosis showing diurnal variation. CT chest shows an anterior mediastinal mass identified as thymus gland cancer. Which receptor is affected in this patient?

choices.text: Voltage-gated calcium channels at the NMJ

questions.solution:
Correct Option B.- Post-synaptic ACh Receptor:

Explanation:

Myasthenia gravis (MG) is an autoimmune disorder in which antibodies target post-synaptic nicotinic acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction, impairing neuromuscular transmission. Thymic abnormalities (hyperplasia or thymoma) are common in MG.

In MG, antibody-mediated blockade and destruction of post-synaptic ACh receptors reduce the number of available receptors, leading to muscle weakness. Weakness worsens with activity and improves with rest (diurnal variation). The association with thymoma is due to aberrant immune activation in the thymus.

Key features: Ptosis, diplopia, dysphagia, proximal muscle weakness, preserved reflexes, and response to acetylcholinesterase inhibitors.

Myasthenia Gravis:

  • Epidemiology: More common in young women and older men.
  • Pathophysiology: Autoantibodies against post-synaptic nicotinic ACh receptors at NMJ → impaired depolarization of muscle fibers.
  • Association: Thymic hyperplasia (65%) and thymoma (15%).
  • Diagnosis: Edrophonium (Tensilon) test, anti-AChR antibody assay, repetitive nerve stimulation showing decremental response.
  • Treatment: Acetylcholinesterase inhibitors (pyridostigmine), immunosuppressants, thymectomy (if thymoma present), plasmapheresis/IVIG for crisis.

NMJ disorders:

Disorder

Site of defect

Antibody target / mechanism

Myasthenia gravis

Post-synaptic membrane

Nicotinic ACh receptor

Lambert–Eaton syndrome

Presynaptic terminal

Voltage-gated calcium channels

Botulism

Presynaptic terminal

Inhibits ACh release (toxin action)

Incorrect Options:

Presynaptic ACh receptor (Option A) – No such pathology in MG; presynaptic issues are rare in autoimmune NMJ disease.

Voltage-gated calcium channels at NMJ (Option C) – Targeted in Lambert–Eaton myasthenic syndrome, not MG.

Acetylcholinesterase (Option D) – This enzyme breaks down ACh in synaptic cleft; it is inhibited pharmacologically in MG treatment, not attacked by antibodies.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female with progressive limb weakness for the past 1 year. On examination, muscle fasciculations and hypertonia are noted, and the sensory system is intact. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - ALS (Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis)

Explanation:

ALS is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder involving both upper motor neurons (UMN) and lower motor neurons (LMN), leading to weakness, hypertonia, and fasciculations, while sparing the sensory system. The presence of UMN signs (hypertonia) and LMN signs (fasciculations) together is characteristic.

ALS affects motor neurons in the motor cortex, brainstem, and spinal cord.

  • UMN involvement → spasticity, hyperreflexia
  • LMN involvement → muscle atrophy, fasciculations, weakness.
  • Sensory pathways are usually preserved, helping differentiate from other neuropathies.
  • Onset is insidious and relentlessly progressive, leading to respiratory failure.

ALS:

  • Epidemiology: Usually presents in middle age; more common in men.
  • Pathophysiology: Degeneration of corticospinal tracts (UMN) and anterior horn cells (LMN).
  • Clinical features: Combination of UMN + LMN signs in multiple regions, no sensory loss.
  • Diagnosis: Clinical (exclusion of mimics), EMG shows denervation and reinnervation.
  • Prognosis: Progressive; most patients die within 3–5 years from respiratory failure.
  • Treatment: Riluzole (glutamate inhibitor) modestly prolongs survival; supportive care is key.

LMN and UMN signs in ALS:

Feature

UMN signs

LMN signs

Tone

Spasticity

Hypotonia

Reflexes

Hyperreflexia, Babinski+

Hyporeflexia

Muscle bulk

Normal initially

Atrophy

Fasciculations

Rare

Common

Incorrect Options:

Spinal muscular atrophy (Option B) – Pure LMN disease; no UMN signs like hypertonia.

Multifocal motor neuropathy (Option C) – Pure LMN weakness, usually asymmetric, often with conduction block on nerve studies.

Becker muscular dystrophy (Option D) – Genetic myopathy with proximal weakness, no UMN signs or fasciculations, and onset typically in adolescence or early adulthood.

questions.text: A patient presents with symmetrical leg weakness and areflexia. He had developed diarrhoea 2 weeks ago. He was diagnosed as having GBS. What is the cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Demyelination of A, B-fibers:

Explanation:

Guillain–Barré Syndrome (GBS) is an acute immune-mediated polyneuropathy, most often triggered by infections like Campylobacter jejuni. It primarily affects myelinated large-diameter motor and sensory fibers (A and B fibers), leading to weakness and areflexia.

A- and B-fibers are myelinated nerve fibers responsible for motor function and some sensory modalities. In GBS, autoantibodies and immune cells attack the myelin sheath, impairing conduction. This demyelination disrupts both motor signals (causing weakness) and reflex arcs (causing areflexia).

Guillain–Barré Syndrome:

  • Trigger: Often post-infectious (e.g., Campylobacter jejuni, CMV, EBV, Mycoplasma).
  • Pathophysiology: Autoimmune-mediated demyelination of peripheral nerves and nerve roots.
  • Clinical features: Symmetrical ascending weakness, areflexia, minimal sensory loss; may involve cranial nerves (bilateral facial palsy).
  • Complications: Respiratory muscle involvement → respiratory failure; autonomic instability.
  • Diagnosis: CSF shows albuminocytologic dissociation (↑ protein, normal cell count); NCS shows slowed conduction velocity.
  • Treatment: IVIG or plasmapheresis; avoid steroids.
  • Prognosis: Most recover fully, but some have residual deficits.

Fiber types affected in GBS:

Fiber Type

Myelination

Function

A fibers

Myelinated

Motor + sensory

B fibers

Myelinated

Preganglionic autonomic

C fibers

Unmyelinated

Pain + temperature

Incorrect Options:

Demyelination of B-fibers (Option B) – B-fibers are affected, but not in isolation; A-fibers are also involved.

Demyelination of the spinal cord (Option C) – GBS is a peripheral neuropathy, not a central spinal cord disorder.

Cord inflammation (Option D) – Suggestive of myelitis, which presents with UMN signs and sensory level, not typical in GBS.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with deep-seated retro-orbital pain of cluster headache. What is the best management?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – Oxygen:

Explanation:

  • High-flow 100% oxygen is the most effective acute abortive therapy for cluster headaches, rapidly relieving pain within 15–20 minutes in most cases. It is safe, well-tolerated, and works faster than most medications.
  • Cluster headaches are severe unilateral headaches with autonomic features. Acute attacks require rapid-acting treatment — high-flow oxygen via a non-rebreather mask or subcutaneous sumatriptan are first-line.
  • Oxygen relieves pain by causing vasoconstriction and possibly modulating trigeminal-autonomic reflexes. Prophylaxis (e.g., verapamil, lithium) is started later to prevent recurrences, but during an acute attack, oxygen is the gold standard.

Cluster Headache:

Feature

Cluster Headache

Pain

Severe, unilateral, retro-orbital/temporal

Duration

15–180 minutes per attack

Frequency

Up to 8/day during cluster periods

Autonomic signs

Lacrimation, conjunctival injection, nasal congestion, ptosis, miosis

Triggers

Alcohol, histamine, nitroglycerin during cluster period

Acute treatment

100% O₂ (12–15 L/min), subcutaneous sumatriptan

Prophylaxis

Verapamil (drug of choice), lithium, topiramate

Incorrect Options:

Verapamil (Option A): Used for prophylaxis, not acute attack.

Lithium (Option C): Alternative prophylactic agent in refractory cases.

Topiramate (Option D): Used in prophylaxis for migraine and sometimes cluster headache, not acute management.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a patient who exhibits miosis, anhidrosis, mild ptosis, and a persistent small pupil even in low light conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Horner syndrome:

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation of miosis, anhidrosis, mild ptosis, and a persistent small pupil even in low light is suggestive of Horner syndrome. Ptosis is a result of the weakness of Müller muscle and miosis due to the unopposed action of the sphincter pupillae with resultant anisocoria.
  • Pancoast tumor can compress the sympathetic nerves, leading to the classic triad of symptoms seen in Horner syndrome: ptosis, miosis (constricted pupil), and ipsilateral facial anhidrosis (lack of sweating).

Acquired Neurogenic Ptosis: Acquired ptosis with drooping of the upper eyelid caused by a disruption in the nerve supply to the muscles responsible for elevating the eyelid.

Causes:

  • Third Cranial (Oculomotor) Nerve Palsy: The third nerve can be damaged by trauma, ischemia, infection, tumor, or compression, causing ptosis and diplopia.Oculomotor nerve palsy causes ptosis as it supplies the levator palpebrae superioris muscle.

The ptotic eyelid can be elevated with a frontalis sling or levator aponeurosis advancement.

  • Horner's Syndrome: Involves a lesion in the sympathetic pathway, affecting the Müller’s muscle, leading to mild ptosis accompanied by miosis (pupil constriction) and anhidrosis (loss of sweating).
  • Ophthalmoplegic migraine
  • Multiple Sclerosis

Diagnosis:

  • Topical apraclonidine test is now considered the test of choice. Apraclonidine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist that also acts as a very weak alpha 1-adrenergic agonist; when topically applied in Horner’s syndrome, it causes dilation of the affected pupil and possibly lid elevation, without change to the normal pupil.

Incorrect Options:

Adie’s tonic people (Option A) It is a unilateral condition and is characterized by anisocoria (different size of pupil) and direct light reflex is sluggish or absent.

Marcus gunn pupil (Option C) Aka relative afferent pupillary defect is characterized by paradoxical dilatation of both the pupil when light is flashed on the diseased eye.

Argyll Robertson pupil (Option D) It is a specific sign of late-stage syphilis. The bilaterally small pupils do not constrict when exposed to bright light.

questions.text: A patient had a road traffic accident (RTA). NCCT head was normal on admission. The patient later died after several days in the ICU due to coma. Brain biopsy revealed multiple punctate hemorrhages. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Diffuse axonal injury (DAI):

Explanation:

  • Diffuse axonal injury is a primary brain injury caused by shearing forces during high-velocity trauma (e.g., RTA).
  • These forces disrupt axons in the white matter, corpus callosum, and brainstem.
  • On initial imaging, NCCT may be normal or show only tiny petechial hemorrhages; the condition is often diagnosed clinically or via MRI.
  • Histopathology (or biopsy) reveals multiple punctate hemorrhages in deep white matter tracts.
  • DAI often leads to immediate or prolonged coma without a lucid interval and carries a high mortality rate.

 

Incorrect Options:

Ischemic injury (Option A): Usually presents with territorial infarcts and hypoxic changes, not punctate hemorrhages in white matter.

Intraventricular bleeding (Option C): Would be evident on CT and localized to ventricular system, not diffuse white matter punctate hemorrhages.

Subdural hemorrhage (Option D): Characterized by crescent-shaped collection on CT, caused by tearing of bridging veins — not microscopic hemorrhages.

questions.text: The infant is being evaluated for recurrent episodes of seizures. ECG shows Hypsarrhythmia. Which drug is preferred for management?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - ACTH

Explanation:

  • Hypsarrhythmia on EEG is characteristic of infantile spasms (West syndrome), a severe epileptic encephalopathy in infants.
  • The first-line treatment is adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), which helps reduce spasms and improve developmental outcomes.

Incorrect Options:

Vigabatrin (Option B): Also effective, especially in infantile spasms associated with tuberous sclerosis, but ACTH remains the preferred initial therapy in most cases.

Valproate (Option C): Used for other seizure types, but less effective for infantile spasms.

Carbamazepine (Option D): Not effective and may worsen infantile spasms.

questions.text: A patient presents with contralateral face, arm, and leg weakness. NCCT shows intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH). What is the most likely location of the CNS bleed?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Basal ganglia

Explanation:

  • Intracerebral hemorrhages causing contralateral hemiparesis (weakness of face, arm, and leg) most commonly occur in the basal ganglia, especially the putamen.
  • The basal ganglia hemorrhage compresses the internal capsule where corticospinal fibers run, causing dense contralateral motor deficits.

Incorrect Options:

Midbrain (Option B): Lesions here often cause oculomotor nerve palsy and contralateral weakness but are less common sites for primary ICH.

Pons (Option C): Hemorrhages can cause "locked-in" syndrome or quadriplegia, often accompanied by cranial nerve signs, but less isolated hemiparesis.

Medulla (Option D): Hemorrhages here are rare; symptoms include contralateral limb weakness with ipsilateral cranial nerve deficits (Wallenberg syndrome) but not classic hemiparesis alone.

questions.text: Patient came with fever headache and nuchal rigidity. LP shows gram negative diplococci in gram stain. Which of the following will be used for chemoprophylaxis in close contacts of a patient with meningococcal meningitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Rifampicin

Rifampicin is the drug of choice for chemoprophylaxis of close contacts of patients with Neisseria meningitidis meningitis. It eradicates nasopharyngeal carriage and prevents secondary cases.

  • Alternatives for those intolerant to rifampicin include ciprofloxacin (adults) and ceftriaxone (pregnancy).

Amoxicillin (Option A): DOC for Listeria meningitis & used for certain bacterial infections, but ineffective for eradicating meningococcal carriage.

Doxycycline (Option B): Tetracycline antibiotic, not used for meningococcal chemoprophylaxis.

Ethambutol (Option C): Anti-tubercular drug, no role in meningococcal prophylaxis.

questions.text: Patient came with severe headache and seizures. Sodium on admission was 98 meq/L. We have started correction with 3% saline and now after 24 hours of infusion sodium is 110 meq/L. Patient develops mutism and altered sensorium. Which investigation will you perform now?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) MRI Head

Explanation: MRI Head is done because this patient likely developed Osmotic Demyelination Syndrome (Central Pontine Myelinolysis) due to rapid correction of chronic hyponatremia.

  • Safe correction: ≤ 8–10 mEq/L in 24 hours.
  • Here, sodium increased by 12 mEq/L in 24 hrs → high risk of demyelination.
  • Symptoms of ODS: mutism, quadriparesis, pseudobulbar palsy, altered consciousness.
  • MRI brain is the investigation of choice

LP for CSF biochemistry (Option B): Not useful; ODS is not an infectious/inflammatory process and CSF is typically normal.

Brainstem evoked potentials (Option C): May detect conduction abnormalities but is not first-line for diagnosis.

EEG (Option D): May show nonspecific slowing in encephalopathy, but will not confirm ODS.

questions.text: A patient presents with sudden onset aphasia and right sided arm weakness for past 4 hours. Which of the following investigations will be done to determine etiology of this case presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Carotid doppler

Explanation: The clinical presentation is suggestive of an acute ischemic stroke in the left MCA territory. Once the patient is stabilized and urgent neuroimaging (CT/MRI) is performed to confirm stroke, the next step in determining etiology in an older patient without known cardiac embolic source is to assess for carotid artery stenosis, a major cause of anterior circulation strokes.

  • Carotid Doppler is a rapid, non-invasive, and reliable tool to detect atherosclerotic plaques and flow-limiting stenosis, which guides further management (e.g., carotid endarterectomy).

Transthoracic echocardiography (Option A): Useful for detecting cardiac sources of emboli, but in most non-cardioembolic stroke presentations, carotid disease is more likely. Usually done later if cardioembolic cause is suspected.

Transesophageal echocardiography (Option C): More sensitive for detecting left atrial appendage thrombi, patent foramen ovale, or aortic plaques, but it is not the first-line investigation for etiology in this presentation.

MRI brain (Option D): This is important for confirming diagnosis and defining extent/location of stroke, but it does not determine the cause, it is diagnostic for the event, not etiologic for the source.

questions.text: A child is brought with a 2-week history of not feeding well and excessive irritability. History of TB for sister is present and is taking treatment for it. In workup, LP was performed. Which of the following is likely to be found in CSF?

choices.text: Lymphocytosis, low sugar, and high protein
Lymphocytosis, high sugar, and high protein
Neutrophils, low sugar and low protein
Neutrophils, low sugar and high protein

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Lymphocytosis, low sugar and high protein:

  • This option is the most likely finding in the CSF of a child with a suspected tuberculous meningitis, which is caused by the bacterium Mycobacterium tuberculosis. The history of TB in the sister raises the suspicion of an infectious etiology.
  • Examination of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) reveals a high leukocyte count (up to 1000/μL), usually with a predominance of lymphocytes but sometimes with a predominance of neutrophils in the early stage; a protein content of 1–8 g/L (100–800 mg/dL); and a low glucose concentration.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Lymphocytosis, high sugar and high protein: While lymphocytosis and high protein levels are expected in a CNS infection, high sugar levels (hyperglycorrhachia) are not typical. Viruses and certain bacteria tend to decrease CSF glucose levels due to increased consumption. Therefore, this option is less likely.

Option C - Neutrophils, low sugar, and low protein: Neutrophils are a type of white blood cell associated with bacterial infections. The combination of low sugar and low protein levels is not characteristic of most CNS infections, as infections typically lead to increased protein levels due to the inflammatory response. This pattern is not consistent with the clinical presentation and history provided.

Option D - Neutrophils, low sugar, and high protein: While neutrophils could be present in the CSF in cases of acute bacterial meningitis, the combination of low sugar and high protein levels is not typical. Acute bacterial infections tend to lower CSF glucose levels due to consumption, but they also lead to an increase in protein levels. This option does not match the expected pattern for the given clinical scenario.

questions.text: In hypoglossal nerve injury, which of the following is seen?

choices.text: Tongue deviation to the contralateral side
Tongue deviation to the same side

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Tongue deviation to the same side:

  • The hypoglossal nerve is the 12th cranial nerve that controls the movement of the tongue. 
  • When the hypoglossal nerve is injured, tongue deviation to the same side as the injury is the most common symptom. This is because the muscles on the affected side of the tongue become weak or paralyzed while the muscles on the unaffected side remain functional. 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Tongue deviation to the contralateral side: Tongue deviation to the contralateral side is incorrect as it suggests that the tongue would move towards the opposite side of the injury. However, this is not a typical presentation of hypoglossal nerve injury.

Option C - Falling of the tongue: Falling of the tongue is also incorrect, as this is a nonspecific symptom that could occur due to various reasons, including weakness or paralysis of the tongue muscles. 

Option D - Inability in tongue protrusion: Inability in tongue protrusion is also incorrect. This symptom would suggest complete paralysis of the tongue muscles on the affected side, which is not always the case with hypoglossal nerve injury.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis for a 24-year-old female patient who presents with fever, headache, ataxia, nausea, and vomiting for the past 3 days? The patient exhibits neck rigidity and hip and knee flexion upon passive flexion of the neck. A lumbar puncture was performed, and the CSF findings are provided below.   	Opening pressure – increased  	Color – cloudy white  	WBCs – 7000/µl; neutrophil predominant  	Sugar – 15 mg/dl  	CSF/serum glucose ratio – 0.2 	Protein – 70 mg/dl 	Latex agglutination – positive  	Limulus lysate test – negative
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Bacterial meningitis:

  • The clinical presentation of the patient, including fever, headache, ataxia, nausea, vomiting, and neck rigidity, suggests meningitis. The findings from the CSF analysis also support this diagnosis.
  • The presence of increased opening pressure, cloudy white color, neutrophil-predominant leukocytosis, low CSF/serum glucose ratio, and elevated protein levels are all indicative of meningitis.
  • The positive latex agglutination test and negative Limulus lysate test suggest bacterial etiology.

Incorrect Options: 

Option B - Tubercular meningitis. The positive latex agglutination test is suggestive of tuberculosis, and the presence of neutrophil-predominant leukocytosis is typical of early-stage tubercular meningitis. The low CSF/serum glucose ratio is also a characteristic finding in tubercular meningitis. But it is not the correct option.

Option C - Viral meningitis: In viral meningitis, the CSF typically shows lymphocytic pleocytosis, with normal or slightly elevated protein levels and normal glucose levels.

Option D - Fungal meningitis can also present with similar symptoms and CSF findings, including increased opening pressure, low glucose, and elevated protein. However, fungal meningitis is rare and usually occurs in immunocompromised individuals.

questions.text: Which of the following type of hypersensitivity reactions is seen in myasthenia gravis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Type 2 hypersensitivity reaction:

  • The type of hypersensitivity reaction seen in myasthenia gravis is a type 2 hypersensitivity reaction. Hypersensitivity reactions are exaggerated immune responses that can cause tissue damage and disease. 
  • Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune disease, most commonly (80% of cases) caused by antibodies to acetylcholine receptors in the post-junctional membrane of the neuromuscular junction.
  • The autoantibodies in myasthenia gravis are primarily of the IgG subtype and lead to complement-mediated destruction of the acetylcholine receptors.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Type 1 hypersensitivity reaction: These reactions typically occur within minutes of exposure and can cause symptoms such as hives, itching, and anaphylaxis.

Option C - Type 3 hypersensitivity reaction: Examples of type 3 hypersensitivity reactions include systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and rheumatoid arthritis.

Option D - Type 4 hypersensitivity reaction: Examples of type 4 hypersensitivity reactions include contact dermatitis and some forms of drug reactions.

questions.text: Which of the following is not one of the key clinical features used to diagnose Lewy body dementia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Orthostatic hypotension:

  • This option is correct. Orthostatic hypotension, which refers to a drop in blood pressure upon standing, is not a core clinical feature of LBD. While some individuals with LBD may experience orthostatic hypotension, it is not specific to the diagnosis and can be seen in other neurological or cardiovascular conditions as well.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Fluctuating cognition: This is a core clinical feature of Lewy body dementia (LBD). Patients with LBD commonly experience variations in cognitive function, such as fluctuations in attention, alertness, and ability to process information.

Option B - Recurrent visual hallucinations: This is a core clinical feature of LBD. Visual hallucinations, often vivid and detailed, are a common symptom in LBD.

Option C - REM sleep behavior disorder (RBD): This is a core clinical feature of LBD and considered prodromal symptom. RBD refers to a disturbance during REM sleep where individuals physically act out their dreams, sometimes leading to injury or harm to themselves or their bed partners.
